questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD with a constellation of features such as impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of femoral pulses. The image below shows the findings seen in the leg. In which of the following conditions are the patient's features seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome.

Leriche syndrome is a rare form of aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD) that presents with the triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses.

Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery causes claudication of the buttock or thigh. Absent distal pulses, bruit over the aortoiliac region, and associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen.

Investigations that are useful include Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, ankle-brachial pressure index, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA).

Management is by exercise, smoking cessation, control of diabetes, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as HMG CoA reductase inhibitors and 75 mg of clopidogrel or aspirin should be given. Transluminal angioplasty and stenting are useful.

The other options are sound-alike signs/syndromes.

Lemmel syndrome: This is obstructive jaundice caused by a periampullary duodenal diverticulum compressing the intrapancreatic part of the common bile duct, with resultant upstream dilatation of the extra- and intrahepatic bile ducts.

Lhermitte sign: This refers to shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.

Lemierre syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of an oropharyngeal infection. The organism involved is typically a fusiform bacillus. The condition presents with severe neck pain, septicemia, or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with an infection of the upper aerodigestive tract.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was rescued from a neglected household. The girl was in severe malnutrition and was therefore fed high-calorie meals at the rehabilitation home. She developed confusion and seizures. Investigations revealed that her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels were low. These electrolyte abnormalities are due to excessive administration of ____.
questions.solution:
The child in this case is suffering from refeeding syndrome, and her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels are low due to the increased serum insulin levels, which in turn is caused due to the excessive administration of carbohydrates.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting refeeding.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following:

  • Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Hypophosphatemia can produce the following manifestations:

  • Cardiac: Hypotension, Decreased stroke volume
  • Respiratory: Impaired diaphragm contractility, Dyspnea, Respiratory failure
  • Neurologic: Paresthesia, Weakness, Confusion, Disorientation, Lethargy, Areflexic paralysis, Seizures, Coma
  • Hematologic: Leukocyte dysfunction, Hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia

A controlled transition over 3 days is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: You are conducting an experiment on mitochondrial respiration. You add malate/pyruvate and respiration is normal. You add succinate and respiration is normal. When you add another substance in the presence of pyruvate/succinate and malate, respiration is blocked. Which of the following substances is most likely added?
questions.solution:
In the experiment conducted on mitochondrial respiration, respiration will be blocked by the addition of oligomycin, an antibiotic, when added in the presence of pyruvate/ succinate and malate. Oligomycin inhibits oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria and hence blocks respiration.

Electron transport chain (ETC)/respiratory chain is the final pathway by which all the electrons derived from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids are directed towards the final reaction with oxygen, to form water and adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

The chemiosmotic theory states that the flow of electrons through the respiratory chain generates a proton motive force. This force drives the formation of ATP by the process of oxidative phosphorylation.

Complexes of ETC     Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-CoQ oxidoreductase Piericidin, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-CoQ reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: CoQH2-cytochrome c oxidoreductase BAL(British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: cytochrome oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
Complex V (informally): ATP Synthase Atractyloside, oligomycin


In the given experiment, malate and pyruvate are electron donors (NADH) at complex I of the ETC, and succinate is the electron donor (FADH2) at complex II. Normal respiration is observed on the addition of substances at both complexes I and II i.e., both oxygen consumption and ATP synthesis from ADP (adenosine diphosphate) take place.

Oligomycin is a competitive inhibitor of the Fo (oligomycin-sensitive) complex of ATP synthase (complex V) and blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by stopping the flow of protons through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. Hence the addition of oligomycin will inhibit complex V and stop respiration.


Other options:

Options A and B: Rotenone (option A) if added, will inhibit complex I. Electron transfer before complex I will be blocked but not after. Hence, normal respiration will occur. Similarly, antimycin A (option B) inhibits complex III, and electron transfer prior to complex III will be blocked and not after. Hence, respiration will not be completely hindered.

Option C: 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) is an uncoupler that dissociates oxidation in the respiratory chain from phosphorylation. Hence, respiration continues without ATP synthesis.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme
Iodoacetate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Arsenate Phosphoglycerate kinase
Fluoride Enolase

 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme
Fluoroacetate Aconitase

Arsenite

 α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Malonate Succinate dehydrogenase

 

Inhibitors of electron transport

Complex Inhibitors
Complex I Piercidin, Amobarbital, Rotenone
Complex II TTFA, Carboxin, Malonate
Complex III BAL, Antimycin A
Complex IV Hydrogen sulphide, Carbon monoxide, Cyanide

 

Inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation

Agent Mechanism
Atractyloside Inhibits ADP and ATP Transporter
Oligomycin Blocks flow of protons through Fo complex

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was diagnosed to have a brain tumor. The histological appearance of the excised tumor is shown in the image given below. What is the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation status of this patient most likely to be?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the histological image showing extensive necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, is suggestive of glioblastoma, which is commonly associated with IDH-wild-type mutations.

Gliomas constitute the most common type of primary brain tumor. They are classified as follows:

  • Astrocytomas
    • Localized type- eg. pilocytic astrocytoma (grade 1)
    • Diffuse infiltrating type- Can be IDH mutant or IDH wild type
      • Diffuse astrocytoma (grade 2)
      • Anaplastic astrocytoma (grade 3)
      • Glioblastoma (grade 4)
  • Oligodendrogliomas- IDH mutant, 1p/19q co-deletion
  • Ependymomas- NF2 gene mutations
Glioblastoma affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis. The majority of the tumors (90%) have IDH wild-type mutation, and the remaining have IDH mutant type.

Clinically, the patient presents with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.

 

Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—a dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

 

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes.

The image given below shows MRI findings seen in glioblastomas. Note the butterfly morphology of the tumor:

 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen
Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S

questions.solution:
Increased (and not decreased) platelet number and aggregability cause hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome.

Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to all of the following factors:

  • Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
  • Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen
  • Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S
  • Increased platelet number and aggregability

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with loss of memory, urinary incontinence, and decreased ability to perform day-to-day activities. She is oriented to time and place, but not to person. On gait assessment, you notice a hypokinetic magnetic gait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia, hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Frontotemporal dementia is a group of syndromes that is characterized by frontotemporal lobar degeneration. The most common variant, the behavioral variant, presents with social and emotional dysfunction which manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, overeating, and may have deficits in executive control.

Option C - Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by tremors at rest, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait dysfunction, postural instability, speech difficulty, swallowing impairment, and autonomic disturbances. 

Option D - Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a degenerative brain disorder due to prions that leads to rapid mental deterioration, usually within a few months with associated myoclonus and behavioral changes.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient was diagnosed with parkinsonism. She was commenced on combination therapy with co-careldopa. What is the rationale behind this combination therapy?

choices.text: To decrease the plasma half life of levodopa
To inhibit the metabolism of levodopa in brain
To promote the metabolism of levodopa in periphery
To reduce the systemic side effects of levodopa

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the combination therapy of levodopa with a peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor like carbidopa (co-careldopa) is that inhibition of the metabolism of levodopa (i.e. conversion of levodopa into dopamine) in the peripheral circulation decreases the systemic side effects of levodopa, like vomiting.

Peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (carbidopa) do not cross the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, they only inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine in the periphery and not in the brain. This leads to the increased plasma half-life of levodopa, and therefore, lower doses of levodopa can be prescribed.

Benefits of combination therapy:

  • This therapy inhibits the metabolism of levodopa in the periphery, leading to increased plasma half-life of levodopa.
  • Combination therapy reduces adverse effects like gastrointestinal side effects, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
  • This therapy allows for increased availability of levodopa in the brain.
  • Fluctuation in motor control, where the patient is alternately well and disabled, occurs on prolonged therapy with levodopa. This type of "on-off" effect is reduced in combination therapy because of sustained dopamine levels in the brain.
  • Pyridoxine enhances the peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Hence, combination therapy with carbidopa nullifies the interaction of pyridoxine with levodopa metabolism.
  •  A higher degree of improvement is seen in combination therapy than in monotherapy with levodopa.

Demerits of combination therapy:

This therapy decreases the concentration of levodopa in the periphery, but increases the concentration of levodopa reaching the brain. Involuntary movements and behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, and delusions are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa. In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral carboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.

Related Pearl: Medical treatment of Parkinson's disease

Increase dopaminergic action Anti cholinergics

Dopamine precursor       

 Anti muscarinic
Levodopa Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl)
Dopa decarboxylase inhibitor Benztropine
Carbedopa Procyclidine
Benserazide H1 antagonist
Dopamine agonist-Ergot derivatives Promethazine
Bromocriptine Orphenadrine
Cabergoline Diphenhydramine
Pergolide  
Lisuride  
Dopamine agonist-Non ergot derivatives  
Ropinirole  
Pramipexole  
Rotigotine  
Apomorphine  
Dopamine facilitator  
Amantadine  
MAO-B inhibitor  
Selegiline  
Rasagiline  
COMT inhibitor  
Tolcapone  
Entacapone

questions.text:
A 7-year-old male patient presented with short trunk dwarfism. Findings of ocular examination are shown in the given image. The child was assessed and was found to be of normal intelligence, and a provisional diagnosis of MPS IV was made. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this child?

MPS IV - Mucopolysaccharidosis IV
questions.solution:
The given image shows corneal clouding, which is a feature seen in mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) IV. Impaired hearing is not seen in MPS IV. 

MPS-IV, also known as Morquio disease, is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase (MPS-IVA) or of β-galactosidase (MPS IVB). Deficiency of either of these enzymes results in defective degradation of keratan sulfate. MPS-IVA is usually more severe than MPS-IVB, with the adult height being <125 cm in MPS-IVA and >150 cm in MPS-IVB.

MPS IV is characterized by short trunk dwarfism and normal intelligence. 

Early symptoms of MPS-IV:

  • Genu valgus
  • Kyphosis
  • Growth retardation with short trunk and neck
  • Waddling gait
  • Tendency to fall.

Impaired hearing is seen in all MPS except MPS IV. Visceromegaly and leukocyte inclusions are characteristically absent in MPS-IV.

Extra-skeletal manifestations include corneal clouding, small teeth with abnormally thin enamel, frequent caries formation, and occasionally cardiac valvular lesions. Life-threatening atlantoaxial instability due to instability of the odontoid process and ligamentous laxity are characteristic.

Management is by enzyme replacement therapy. A recombinant human GALNS enzyme replacement therapy elosulfase alfa is approved for the treatment of MPS IVA. Treatment has been shown to improve ambulatory mobility and decrease pain, but no effect on growth or skeletal dysplasia. There is no current specific treatment for MPS IVB.

Corneal clouding is absent in Hunter (MPS-II) and Sanfilippo (MPS-III) syndromes.

Note: As a general rule, the impaired degradation of heparan sulfate is more closely associated with mental deficiency and deficiency of dermatan, chondroitin, and keratan sulfate with mesenchymal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of hypertension, presented with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed an aortic dissection involving only the descending thoracic aorta, not extending into the abdominal aorta. According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection is classified as ______.
questions.solution:
According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection limited to the descending thoracic aorta is classified as DeBakey type IIIa.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimo-medial flap. It most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing chest/back pain. It is associated with diaphoresis. Other symptoms are syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.

On examination, there can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological manifestations. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

The image given below shows aortic dissection in the thoracic aorta with the true lumen as well as the false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen.

The flowchart given below sums up the management algorithm for aortic dissection.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Among the fetal blood vessels mentioned above, the superior vena cava (SVC) has the lowest oxygen concentration. It carries deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium.

The pO2 of SVC is about 12-14 mm Hg whereas the pO2 of the umbilical artery is about 20-25 mm Hg. This is because the SVC carries only deoxygenated blood, whereas the umbilical artery carries a mix of oxygenated blood from ascending aorta and deoxygenated blood from systemic circulation.

Fetal circulation:

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities, carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. 

The blood then enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives purely deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This blood then enters the pulmonary artery. Since fetal lungs are collapsed, most of the blood enters the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus and is then distributed to the body. 

Finally, some of this blood from the aorta and the lower parts of the body is pumped back to the placenta via umbilical arteries. Hence, they contain a mix of both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. 

The rough estimate of oxygenation of the vessels in the fetal circulation is given below:

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman presented with a low-grade fever and colicky pain in the right hypochondrium. Scleral icterus and tenderness in the right hypochondrium were noted. Ultrasound showed the following finding in the enlarged common bile duct (measuring 9 mm). Investigations reveal deranged liver function tests. Which of the following would be best suited for her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonograph indicate a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis. The next best step in the management of this patient is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

Symptoms of fever and obstructive jaundice symptoms such as scleral icterus, light-colored stools, and dark-colored urine point toward a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis.

The first investigation, in this case, is a USG to look for biliary duct dilation and determine whether it is intra- or extrahepatic. Once this is confirmed, ERCP can be done as it can remove the stone without operative intervention. 

Common indications for ERCP:

  • Relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease (can present as unexplained jaundice)
  • Biliary drainage
  • Biliary stenting for strictures and leakage
  • Biliary or pancreatic ductal system tissue sampling
  • Balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures
  • Sphincterotomy
  • Sphincter of Oddi manometry

ERCP utilizes a side-viewing endoscope through which it identifies and is able to cannulate the Ampulla of Vater. A water-soluble contrast is then injected into the common bile duct. It helps in identifying stones or strictures.

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is used in case of unsuccessful ERCP or anatomical difficulty for EŖCP.

The below image shows a schematic diagram of ERCP:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

 

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

 

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with severe, worsening abdominal pain since the previous day. He had undergone angioplasty for coronary artery disease 2 years back. The patient was hemodynamically stable. On examination, a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdomen. Ultrasound revealed an intact abdominal aortic aneurysm of diameter 4.5 cm. What should be the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Follow-up every 6 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm
Follow-up every 2 months; operate if diameter is >5 cm
Immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm
Follow-up every 3 months; operate if diameter is >5.5 cm

questions.solution:
The management of a patient with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm is immediate surgical repair of the aneurysm.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm. The most important risk factor to develop AAA is atherosclerosis. In the majority of cases, it occurs below the renal arteries.

Risk factors for AAA are age, male sex, atherosclerosis, smoking history, hypertension, and connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

The patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms of abdominal pain or back pain. They might have a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. The patients are hemodynamically stable in case of an intact aneurysm. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass.

Abdominal ultrasound can be used, but only a CT scan is useful in the diagnosis of an aneurysm.

Treatment:

Surgical repair of AAA is indicated in

  • Symptomatic patients/ patients with a ruptured aneurysm
  • Asymptomatic patients if the diameter is >5.5 cm
  • Rapidly enlarging AAA, increasing in diameter by >0.5 cm within 6 months
  • Those associated with peripheral artery aneurysms undergoing repair

Surgical options for the repair of aortic aneurysms are endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open aneurysm repair. EVAR is preferred over open aneurysm repair in current practice.

The other options are incorrect. The frequency for follow-up is every 6 months if the AAA has a diameter of <5.5 cm. 

Related Pearl: Indications for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm

Clinical scenario Indication for operative repair
Symptomatic aneurysm Any size
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm
When the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased > 0.5 cm per year
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter or > 6 cm
When the diameter of descending  aortic aneurysm has increased  > 1 cm per year
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve 4-5cm

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated, multiple, long bone fractures. On examination, blue sclera and dental abnormalities are noted. Family history is positive. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (or brittle bone disease) is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations (blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

The images below show blue sclera and wormian bones in osteogenesis imperfecta:

Other options:

Option A: Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with disproportionately short limbs, sleep apnea, and kyphoscoliosis. Facial features include button nose, frontal bossing, and macrocephaly. 

The images below show the features of achondroplasia:

(a) Prominent forehead and body asymmetry, (b) a low nasal bridge, (c) trident hands, (d) scoliosis 

Option C: Cretinism occurs due to iodine deficiency. Its clinical features are deaf-mutism, squint, mental retardation, and spastic or rigid neuromotor disorder. 

Option D: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. The affected persons will be tall with long limbs and digits. Spontaneous pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and lens dislocation are also seen. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation.

Related Pearl: Subtypes of Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

Subtypes

Blue sclera

Normal stature

Hearing impairment

Joint laxity

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant

 

Prognosis- 

Compatible with survival

Subtype II- 

Abnormally short pro-α1(1) chain Unstable triple helix Abnormal or insufficient pro-α2(1)

Death in utero or within days of birth

Skeletal deformity with excessive fragility and multiple fractures

Blue sclera

Inheritance- 

Most are autosomal recessive Few are autosomal dominant

 

Prognosis- 

Perinatal lethal

Subtype III-

Altered structure of pro-peptides of pro-α2(1)

Impaired formation of triple helix

 

Growth retardation

Multiple fractures

Progressive kyphoscoliosis

Blue sclera at birth that become white

Hearing impairment

Short pro-α2(1) chain Unstable triple helix

Postnatal fractures

normal sclerae

Short stature

Sometimes dentinogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: A 23-year-old football player is brought unresponsive to the emergency room, following trauma to the head. His teammates recall that he was alert and responsive for a brief period in the locker room before he became unconscious. Physical examination now shows a GCS of 6 with anisocoria. Pulse rate is 53 beats/minute, blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 10 breaths/minute. Head CT images are shown below. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing lens-shaped hemorrhage is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma is the definitive management of this condition.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) is also known as an epidural hematoma. It is a collection of blood between the outer layer of the dura and the inner surface of the skull, which is called the periosteal layer. The bleeding is most commonly due to torn middle meningeal artery.

EDH is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture. It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Epidural hematoma may present with a transient loss of consciousness immediately after the trauma, followed by a lucid interval, where consciousness is recovered. The neurological status of the patient subsequently worsens due to continued bleeding from the site, as seen in this patient. This can cause a mass effect, with herniation.

EDH is diagnosed with CT and MRI. CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the cranial sutures but can cross venous sinuses.

The definitive management for any patient with GCS <9 and pupillary abnormalities such as anisocoria is craniotomy, with emergency evacuation of the hematoma. Surgery is also recommended for patients with worsening neurological status and hematoma volume of >30 mL, regardless of neurological status.

The image given below shows a CT scan depicting EDH. Note the biconvex or lens-shaped hematoma.

Other options:

Option A: Hyperventilation lowers the pCO2 and lowers the intracranial pressure (ICP) because of vasoconstriction. But this may also worsen the perfusion in the brain and must be done with caution.

Option B: Intravenous mannitol may be used to lower ICP, but it is not a definitive management option in this patient in a coma.

Option D: Intravenous fluids are not indicated in this condition. It may be used as an adjunct in therapy.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: After crowning was established in a patient in labor, the obstetrician uses the instrument shown below to give a liberal episiotomy. By doing so, what grade of perineal injury is the obstetrician iatrogenically inflicting?
questions.solution:
The image shows an episiotomy scissor, which can be identified by its angulation. It is used to perform an episiotomy. During episiotomy, the obstetrician iatrogenically induces a second-degree perineal tear.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear that involves the perineal muscles but spares the anal sphincter. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Timely episiotomy prevents third and fourth-degree perineal tears, which affect the anal sphincter.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Episiotomies are either midline or mediolateral:

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A population survey recently reported a surge in xerophthalmia cases among children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following options show the prevalence of certain indicators of vitamin A deficiency in the population at risk. Which of them signifies that vitamin A deficiency is a public health problem?

choices.text: Night blindness in >0.05% of the population
Bitot's spots in >0.5% of the population
Corneal scar in >0.01% of the population
Serum retinol less than 10 mcg/dL in >0.1% of the population

questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of Bitot's spots is >0.5%, among several other criteria, in children between 6 months to 6 years of age.

To design an effective intervention program for the prevention of vitamin A deficiency, the first step is to identify the population risk. This is done by conducting population surveys or prevalence surveys that account for both clinical and biochemical criteria.

The surveys are done in preschool children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following are the criteria, recommended by WHO to determine the public health significance of xerophthalmia and vitamin A deficiency.

Criteria 

Prevalence in population at risk(6 months to 6 years) 
Night blindness (XN) >1% 
Bitot’s spots  (X1B) >0.5% 

Corneal xerosis/ corneal ulcer/ Keratomalacia 

(X2/X3A/X3B)

 >0.01% 

Corneal scar

(XS)

 >0.05% 
Serum retinol (<10 mcg/dL)  >5% 

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of limping. He gives a history of fracture a few months back. On examination, his left leg is shorter than his right leg. He undergoes the following procedure. Identify the incorrect statement regarding this procedure.

choices.text: Distraction is done at a rate of 1 mm per day.
It is based on the principle of callotaxis.
It is contraindicated in the presence of osteomyelitis.
It is used to perform arthrodesis.

questions.solution:
The given image shows distraction osteogenesis using the Ilizarov apparatus. Osteomyelitis is not a contraindication for this procedure.

Distraction osteogenesis (distraction histogenesis) is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. This is described as the tension stress effect.

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. This is used in limb lengthening or for the filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings - 0.25 mm, four times a day. It is also used in the following scenarios:

  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

An illustration of distraction osteogenesis using the Ilizarov apparatus and the radiograph depicts the procedure is given below:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a child with the features shown in the given image. On examination, the child had brittle bones, and x-ray scans revealed stippled epiphyses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in causing this teratogenic condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose). This image along with the stippling of bone epiphyses points to fetal warfarin syndrome or warfarin embryopathy. 

Features:

  • Repeated abortions
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Depressed nasal bridge/absent nasal bone/saddle nose at birth
  • Bleeding diathesis at birth
  • Growth retardation - hypoplasia of nose, eye sockets, and long bones with stippling of epiphyses 

Anticoagulation in pregnancy:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, it can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus but is less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: It is inadequate, and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If delivery occurs while the anticoagulant is still effective, and excessive bleeding happens, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

Anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week of gestation. 
  • Heparin is then replaced by a warfarin tablet of 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks in patients with a high risk of thrombosis.
  • Thereafter, warfarin is replaced by heparin, which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH), LMWH, and warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus

Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus

Carbimazole and Methimazole

Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
