questions.text: An elderly man presents for evaluation following an episode of syncope the same day. He reports having fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. 2D-echo shows left ventricular hypertrophy, with an aortic valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. What will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis (AS), which is associated with the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused by the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis:

  • Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. This causes exertional dyspnea.
  • Angina pectoris: It occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery 
  • Syncope: It occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component, or there may be a paradoxical splitting of S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component. The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids. 

Severe AS is defined as the aortic valve area <1 cm2. Patients even with severe AS may be asymptomatic as the left ventricle undergoes hypertrophy to increase the intraventricular pressure and maintain the stroke volume. Symptomatic AS is an indication for valve replacement.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism, and tension pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Grading of Aortic Stenosis

Grading of stenosis

Area of aortic valve

Mild

1.5 – 2 sq cm

Moderate

1 – 1.5 sq cm

Severe

< 1 sq cm

questions.text: An adult weighing 70 kg is brought with 2nd-degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the amount of Ringer lactate that has to be administered in the first 8 hours after sustaining the burn?
questions.solution:
1.3 liters of Ringer lactate has to be infused within the first 8 hours of burn.

The affected percentage of body surface area (BSA) is calculated using Wallace's rule of 9: The anterior part of each lower limb would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA. Thus, a total BSA of 19% is affected.

The fluid resuscitation requirement in a burn patient is calculated using the Parkland formula. It gives the total fluid requirement for the first 24 hours after surviving a burn. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Parkland formula for an adult with 2nd-degree burns is given by: 2 x weight in kg x % TBSA

Thus, the fluid requirement in a 70-kg patient with burns involving 19% of the BSA = 2 x 70 x 19 = 2660 mL.

Only half of 2660 mL is administered within the first 8 hours. Thus, 1330 mL or 1.3 L of fluid has to be administered in the first 8 hours.

The following image shows Wallace's rule of 9:

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A patient develops a sore throat after general anaesthesia. He was diagnosed as having a postoperative sore throat (POST). The anaesthetist injects a local anaesthetic in the plane of the marked structure. Which of the following pierces the marked structure?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels

questions.solution:
The marked structure shows the thyrohyoid membrane. It is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve, along with superior laryngeal vessels. USG-guided block of the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is used in the management of POST. 

The diagram given below shows the structures piercing the thyrohyoid membrane.

The thyrohyoid membrane is a fibroblastic layer connecting the superior border of the thyroid cartilage to the superior border of the body and the greater cornu of the hyoid.

It facilitates the ascent of the larynx during swallowing.

It is pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and the internal laryngeal nerve. It, therefore, serves as the potential target for ultrasound-guided local anaesthetic injection if an internal laryngeal block is needed to alleviate POST.

questions.text: A 38-year-old laborer presents to the district hospital with gradually progressive spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It began as an abnormal gait with short jerky steps, and soon, he was dependent on crutches. His younger brother has developed a similar gait. They have been consuming an inexpensive dal that resembles red gram for the past 2 years. Which of the following compounds is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of neurolathyrism and beta-oxalyl amino-alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus). It has a characteristic triangular shape and grey color. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years, and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA is the toxic compound causing lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Although it is considered irreversible, vitamin C in doses of 500–1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour).

Disease   Food Substance/
Contaminant 		 Toxic Principle 
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus/ Khesari dal  BOAA 
Epidemic
dropsy 		 Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 
Ergotism Bajra, wheat, sorghum, and rye get infested by ergot fungus Claviceps purpurea Ergot alkaloids
Endemic
ascites 		 Crotalaria/
Jhunjhunia 		 Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

questions.text: The device shown below is the most widely used instrument for measuring  _______.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a dry and wet bulb hygrometer. It is the most widely used instrument for measuring the humidity of air. 

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers—a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer—mounted side by side on a stand. 

After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found in psychrometric charts and slides. 

Other instruments used to measure humidity:

  • Sling psychrometer
  • Assmann psychrometer

Other options:

Option B - The mean radiant temperature is measured using a globe thermometer.

Option C - The cooling power of air was originally measured using a kata thermometer. Kata thermometer is now largely used for recording low air velocities. 

Option D - The maximum temperature reached in a given time is measured by a maximum thermometer. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient with breathlessness who is admitted to the emergency department. His BP is 90/56 mmHg. Which clinical finding is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), which are indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Among the given options, pericardial knock is not a clinical feature of cardiac tamponade. It is a sign of constrictive pericarditis. 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to the impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include the following:

  • Pulsus paradoxus - This is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) on inspiration. In tamponade, the increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart causes the interventricular septum to bow towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing the left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 
  • Beck's triad - This is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of hypotension (90/56 mmHg), muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure. Features of JVP in tamponade include prominent x descent and absent y descent. 
  • ECG - ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electrical alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, the amplitude deflection on the ECG is increased; in contrast, when the heart moves away from the chest wall, the amplitude deflection is lower.

Management of cardiac tamponade - In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Note - Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by a progressive fibrotic change in the pericardium that causes it to thicken and calcify. This leads to impaired cardiac contraction and filling. This gives rise to fatigue, elevated JVP (rapid y descent), ascites, and pulsus paradoxus.

A notable finding on cardiac auscultation is the pericardial knock, which is an early diastolic sound. It is best appreciated over the left sternal border and/or the cardiac apex. It represents early and abrupt discontinuation of ventricular filling. 

ECG findings in constrictive pericarditis consist of non-specific T-wave abnormalities. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: An infant is brought by his worried parents with a rash and yellowish discoloration of the skin. On examination, the baby has petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and microcephaly. The developmental assessment shows global developmental delay. An axial cut of the non-contrast CT of the brain is given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly and global developmental delay, with non-contrast CT head showing periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly suggests a congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Infants with congenital CMV infection may present with the following findings: 

  • Petechial rash ("blueberry muffin-like")
  • Jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly
  • Microcephaly
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Periventricular calcification and ventriculomegaly
  • IUGR and prematurity

Option A: Congenital rubella syndrome consists of a triad of cardiac defects, cataracts, and congenital hearing loss.

Option B: Neonatal herpes presents as skin lesions with eye involvement, encephalitis, and disseminated disease.

Option D: Fetal varicella syndrome is manifested as cicatricial skin lesions, chorioretinitis, hypoplastic limbs, low birth weight, and CNS defects due to cerebral atrophy.

Note: In 15-20% of infants with congenital CMV infection, microcephaly is not detected at birth. It may develop as the child grows and is detected at follow-up visits for other complaints.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who presented with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties has been diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the structures marked in the given image is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Duchenne muscular dystrophy: It is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, which is located at Xp21. The resultant lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which results in the progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Clinical features include progressive weakness and developmental delay. Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles are seen. Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristically seen. It may be associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

The image given below shows pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles.

Gower’s sign - The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk up" their own body from a squatting position. This indicates weakness of proximal muscles.

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
  • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Histopathological examination of the muscle biopsy shows fatty replacement of muscle fibers.

The image given below shows the replacement of muscle fibers by adipose cells seen in DMD.

Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Eteplirsen and casimersen are the two new FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of DMD.

The complications of DMD include contractures, scoliosis, dilated cardiomyopathy, and malignant hyperthermia after anesthesia.

Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The skin condition shown in the image is Harlequin ichthyosis.

Harlequin ichthyosis is the most devastating type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis. It occurs due to mutations of the ABCA12 gene. The two other types of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis are lamellar ichthyosis and congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma.

Harlequin ichthyosis is associated with thickened skin over nearly the entire body at birth. Neonates are born with armor-like skin (truncal plates with fissuring). The skin forms large, diamond-shaped plates that are separated by deep cracks.

Early in life, constant supportive care is typically required. Treatment may include moisturizing cream, antibiotics, etretinate, or retinoids.

The image given below shows ichthyosis vulgaris.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is bought to your outpatient department with complaints of bleeding gums. Investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. Further workup revealed a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX. What is the underlying pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX are suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is a disorder of platelet adhesion.

Platelet adhesion normally occurs due to interaction between Gp Ib of the platelets and von Willebrand factor (vWF) of the subendothelium of blood vessels. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the defect in Gp Ib/IX results in impaired adhesion of platelets. This causes a defect in the formation of the primary platelet plug, leading to abnormal bleeding tendency.

Other options:

Option A- Disorder of platelet aggregation - Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a disorder of platelet aggregation. It occurs because of the dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb–IIIa, which is responsible for bridge formation between the platelets by binding fibrinogen.

Option C- Disorder of platelet activation - These are characterized by the defective release of certain mediators of platelet activation, such as thromboxanes and granule-bound ADP. These include platelet storage pool disorders and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Option D- Disorder of platelet production - These may include disorders involving ineffective hematopoiesis such as leukemias and bone marrow failure or they may be drug-induced.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild thrombocytopenia  Normal Normal (except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)
Platelet morphology Large platelets/ megathrombocytes with dense granules Normal  Normal/ large
Bleeding time

Prolonged

 Prolonged  Prolonged
Platelet aggregation tests (collagen, ADP, thrombin) Normal Abnormal  Normal
Ristocetin aggregation test

Abnormal (platelets does not aggregate)

Does not normalize after addition of normal serum

Normal

(aggregation of platelets)

 Abnormal, Normalizes after addition of normal serum
VWF factor levels Normal Normal  Decreased
PT/PTT Normal Normal  PT normal, aPTT prolonged

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency room with a high-grade fever. On examination, bilaterally enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes are present. The findings of peripheral smear examination are shown in the image given below.  Which of the following is a causative organism in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with two nuclei at the tail tip are suggestive of infection with Brugia malayi.

The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi:

  • Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti.
  • Shows kinks and secondary curves.
  • Cephalic space is longer.
  • Carries double stylets at the anterior end.
  • Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films.
  • Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The image given below shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Filariasis: In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis, referred to as Bancroftian filariasis which is transmitted by C. quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). Brugia malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the mansonia mosquito.

It occurs due to the transmission of filariform larva (stage III larva), whereas, microfilaria is the larval stage that circulates in the human blood, which is ingested by mosquitoes during the blood meal. The extrinsic incubation period (duration of the mosquito cycle) is 10-14 days and the reservoirs of infection are humans (predominantly in India) and animals.

Classical filariasis is due to the obstruction of lymphatics by the adult worms, which results in lymph stasis. This leads to the leakage of lymph into the tissues, causing hard-pitting (brawny) oedema. It can present as acute adenolymphangitis, hydrocele, or elephantiasis (shown below).

Occult filariasis (Meyers-Kouwenaar syndrome) results from a hypersensitivity reaction to the microfilarial antigens. Here, the microfilariae are not found in the blood. Symptoms include hepatosplenomegaly, nocturnal cough, or arthritis. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a sign of occult filariasis, characterized by low-grade fever, weight loss, dry nocturnal cough, significant eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels.

Management: Diethyl carbamazepine (DEC) is the drug of choice, given orally at a dose of 6 mg/kg body weight for a period of 12 days. In endemic areas, treatment must be repeated every 2 years. A severe allergic reaction may occur due to the death of microfilaria after the treatment which is controlled with corticosteroids and antihistamines. DEC kills both microfilaria and macrofilaria.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

Related Pearl: Indications of Ivermectin

  • Onchocerciasis
  • Chemoprophylaxis of filariasis
  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Gnathostomiasis
  • Scabies
  • Head lice

questions.text: Which of the following osteological features indicate that the skeletal remains are those of a male?

choices.text: Square orbits located lower on the face

questions.solution:
The feature that indicates that the skeletal remains are those of a male is square orbits located lower on the face. The female skull has round orbits with sharp margins, and they are placed higher on the face. 

Other options:

The table below highlights the differences between a male and a female skeleton:

Features Male Female
1. Mastoid process Medium to large-sized with a round and blunt appearance Small to medium-sized with a smooth and relatively pointed appearance
2. Orbits Square-shaped with rounded margins and located lower on the face Round with sharp margins and located higher on the face
3. Greater sciatic notch Narrow and deep Broad and shallow
4. Ischial tuberosities Inverted  Everted

The greater sciatic notch of the pelvis is deemed to be a good indicator for sex determination with an accuracy of 75%.

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

 

To determine the race of an individual -

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. A glycerol test and electrocochleography were performed to diagnose her condition, and promethazine was prescribed for management. A few days later she presents with complaints of a sudden loss of tone without loss of consciousness. She states that she felt like she was pushed to the ground. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Meniere's disease with Tumarkin's otolithic crisis.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is an auditory disease characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

Variants of MD:

  • Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis is not well understood.
  • Lermoyez syndrome - Here, symptoms of MD are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.
  • Vestibular hydrops - Typical episodes of vertigo occur while cochlear function remains intact.
  • Cochlear hydrops - Only cochlear functions are impaired, while vertigo episodes do not appear until later.

Other options

Tullio phenomenon - It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient who is an athlete presents with pruritus of the groin. The findings of examination of the groin are shown in the image given below. He is diagnosed with a fungal infection. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dry, erythematous, and a circumferential lesion in the groin are suggestive of tinea cruris. The most probable causative organism among the given options for tinea cruris is Trichophyton rubrum. 

Tinea cruris, or jock itch, refers to an infection that can involve the genital, pubic, perineal, and perianal skin. It is usually caused by dermatophytes like Trichophyton rubrum or Epidermophyton floccosum. 

T. rubrum belongs to the dermatophyte group. Dermatophytes are classified as microsporum, trichophyton, and epidermophyton. They are hyaline, filamentous fungi that enzymatically digest the keratin. Dermatophytes cause infection of the keratin-containing structures. These include the skin, hair, and nails. 

Infections caused by dermatophytes include the following: 

  • Tinea barbae - beard "barber's itch" 
  • Tinea corporis - affecting the body 
  • Tinea imbricata - a type of tinea corporis that exists in the tropical climate
  • Tinea capitis - scalp 
  • Tinea cruris - groin "jock itch"
  • Tinea pedis - foot "athlete's foot"
  • Tinea manuum - hand
  • Tinea unguium - nails 

The examination will reveal erythematous, pruritic, circular, scaly patches.  

Diagnosis of dermatophyte infection is done with Wood's lamp, which will reveal fluorescence. KOH preparation will reveal branching hyaline septate hyphae. Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is used to culture dermatophytes. 

Topical azoles like miconazole, clotrimazole, or terbinafine are used to treat dermatophyte infections. 

Other options: 

Option A - Exophiala werneckii causes tinea nigra, an infection of the stratum corneum in the areas of the palm, leading to dark macules. 

Option C - Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor. This fungus causes infection of the stratum corneum, leading to discolored or depigmented macules over the thorax, abdomen, and upper limbs. 

Option D - Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra, infection of the hair. It is characterized by firm, irregular nodules on the hair shaft.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is given below. What change does the myosin undergo in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given ECG of a hypertensive patient is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform. 

The given ECG shows tall left precordial R waves, i.e in the V1 lead, and deep right precordial S waves in the V5 and V6 leads, which are over 35 mm. It also shows the presence of repolarization abnormalities in the form of ST depression with T-wave inversions in the right precordial leads. An increased limb lead voltage (R-aVL) also signifies the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of LVH:

  • S-V1 + R-V5/V6 >35 mm
  • R-aVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion- strain pattern

Causes of LVH:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Aortic stenosis
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Cardiac hypertrophy is associated with a switch in gene expression from genes that encode adult-type contractile proteins to genes that encode distinct fetal isoforms of the same proteins. One such example is where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform, which has a slower, more energetically economical contraction.

Cardiac hypertrophy is also associated with increased atrial natriuretic factor gene expression. This causes salt secretion by the kidney and decreases blood volume and pressure, thereby reducing hemodynamic load.

Several regressive changes occur in the myocardial fibers when the enlargement of muscle mass is no longer able to cope with the increased burden. They include degradation and loss of myofibrillar contractile elements. In extreme cases, myocyte death can occur. The net result of these changes is cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic to discuss options for contraception. She has two children but is unsure whether she has completed her family. She has been smoking 4-5 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her menses are regular, but with heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following will be the most ideal contraceptive method for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best contraceptive method for this patient would be a  Norplant (progesterone) subdermal implant. It is one of the most effective contraceptive methods other than sterilization.

This patient is unsure whether she has completed her family, so she cannot be offered surgical sterilization (Option D). Oral contraceptive pills (Option A) are contraindicated in this patient who is a smoker over 35 years of age. Copper-T intrauterine device (Option C) will worsen this patient's heavy menstrual bleeding; therefore, it is not the best choice for this patient. 

Mechanism of action of implants:

  • Inhibits ovulation in 90% of the cycles for the first one year of use
  • Also causes atrophy of the endometrium and cervical mucus thickening

Insertion:

The capsules are inserted subdermally, in the inner aspect of the nondominant arm, 6–8 cm above the elbow fold between the biceps and triceps muscles. 

The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good.
  • They are coitus-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections.
  • Pregnancy rate varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years.

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, and amenorrhea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3% of users.
  • Local infection may occur.
  • The implant requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are, however, minor surgical procedures.
  • The implants are expensive and cost rupees 10,000.

Norplant I  contains six silastic capsules- has been withdrawn and replaced by a single rod implant.

Norplant II (Jadelle) consists of two rods each containing 70 mg LNG. The daily release of hormone is 50 mcg, and it provides contraception for 3–5 years.

Implanon: Amenorrhea is common at the end of 1 year. Acne is reduced, and there is no risk of osteoporosis.

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatric emergency department after she slashed her wrist in an attempt to commit suicide. Her father reveals that there were multiple such attempts in the past. She has a history of marked fluctuations of mood and unstable relationships in the past. Which of the following non-pharmacological therapy is advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy advised for this patient is dialectical behavioral therapy.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP), and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various psychotherapies used in the treatment of this condition. There is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. 

Antipsychotics help to control anger, hostility, and brief psychotic episodes. Antidepressants are used to improve depressive mood which is common in patients with borderline personality disorder.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors help in the modulation of impulsive behavior and benzodiazepine-like alprazolam helps in improving anxiety and depression. Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine help in improving the global functioning of patients with borderline personality disorder. 

Other options:

Interpersonal psychotherapy is used in the treatment of depression. It focuses on grief over loss, interpersonal disputes, interpersonal skill deficits, and role transitions.

Exposure and response prevention is used in the treatment of OCD.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with major depression 3 years back has been on long-term therapy with antidepressants. She comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of reduced libido and difficulty in attaining orgasm. Which of the following drugs is she most likely consuming?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a woman on long-term antidepressant therapy developing sexual dysfunction is most likely to have been caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Sertraline is the SSRI among the given options.

All SSRIs cause sexual dysfunction, and it is the most common adverse effect of SSRIs associated with long-term treatment. Presenting adverse effects include anorgasmia, inhibited orgasm, and decreased libido. Other side effects of SSRIs include the following:

System Side effects of SSRIs
Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal (5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, diarrhoea, anorexia, vomiting, flatulence, and dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, seizures, emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, constipation, sedation
Cardiovascular Drug-induced long QT syndrome
Haematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, galactorrhea

The various classes of drugs used in depression and anxiety are listed below

Class of drugs Examples
Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRI)
  • Fluoxetine
  • Fluvoxamine
  • Paroxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Citalopram
Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors
  • Venlafaxine
  • Desvenlafaxine
  • Duloxetine
  • Milnacipran
Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Amitriptyline
  • Imipramine
  • Nortriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Amoxapine
Atypical antipsychotics
  • Aripiprazole
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Risperidone
Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO)
  • Isocarboxazid
  • Selegiline
  • Phenelzine
Atypical antidepressants
  • Bupropion
  • Trazodone
  • Mirtazapine
  • Mianserin

Other options: 

Option A - Moclobemide is a selective, reversible inhibitor of monoamine oxidase (a) (RIMAs), the most common adverse effects of which are dizziness, nausea, insomnia, or sleep disturbance. RIMAs cause fewer GI adverse effects than SSRIs, and moclobemide has not been reported to interfere with sexual function.

Option C - Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant. Patients taking this drug do not present with sexual dysfunction. Common side effects include a switch to mania/ hypomania in susceptible patients. Patients also exhibit anticholinergic effects, orthostatic hypotension, sedation, and teratogenicity.

Option D - Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts by increasing both norepinephrine and serotonin. The most common side effects seen in mirtazapine use in the order of decreasing frequency are somnolence, dry mouth, increased appetite, constipation, and weight gain.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body, along with a history of frequent falls, diarrhea, and dysentery. She was diagnosed with Hartnup disease. What causes these pellagra-like features in Hartnup disease?

choices.text: Excessive loss of niacin in urine

questions.solution:
Malabsorption of tryptophan leads to pellagra in Hartnup disease.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to the mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on chromosome 5. As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced, and this manifests as pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress, and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia, tremor, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, thus distinguishing it from pellagra. Urine may also contain indican, which is produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Casal’s necklace:

Niacin (Vitamin B3)

It is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan. The active forms of niacin are nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. Nicotinamide is present in NAD and NADP, which are important for oxidation-reduction reactions and ADP ribosylation of proteins involved in the DNA repair mechanism.  

Deficiency of niacin causes pellagra. Important causes are as follows:

  • Dietary deficiencies of niacin or tryptophan
  • Hartnup disease- defective absorption of tryptophan
  • Carcinoid syndrome- enterochromaffin cells increase the production of 5-hydroxytryptamine. This decreases the production of niacin.

Excessive levels of niacin cause dilation of blood vessels, flushing, skin irritation, and liver damage.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: Sagar was being tried in court for the attempted murder of Mohan in the park. Shikhar appeared in court and said that he was told by Raju that Sagar tried to kill Mohan. What is this evidence known as?
questions.solution:
This evidence is known as hearsay evidence. 

Hearsay evidence is given by someone about something that he/she did not personally witness. Sometimes, it might be obtained from a third party. It is presented in the court to claim that the facts contained in the statement are true, i.e. as a means of corroboration. 

Other types of oral evidence:

Direct evidence is the evidence of a fact that is actually in the issue. Examples: a witness saw A shooting B, prescription, consent form.

Indirect evidence is also known as circumstantial evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eyewitness. It has an effect on other facts and subsidiary facts which are depended upon as consistent. 

Documentary evidence is of three types:
  • Medical certificates
  • Medicolegal reports
  • Dying declaration
 A witness is a person who gives evidence regarding facts. There are 2 types of witnesses:
  • Common witness is a person who gives evidence about those facts that are observed or perceived by him/her.
  • Expert witness has the technical knowledge and is capable of drawing conclusions from facts presented (Section 45 of IEA).

A witness can be considered a hostile witness when he/ she has a vested interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving false evidence (Section 191 of IPC).

questions.text: A study was done in 1978 in which babies born between 1969 to 1975 were investigated for the effects of electronic fetal monitoring during labor. The number of neonatal deaths was measured. This is an example of which of the following type of study?
questions.solution:
This is an example of a retrospective cohort study since the outcome (neonatal death) has already occurred before the start of the investigation. The investigators went back in time (1969 to 1975) to select the study groups.

Cohort study: It progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not the disease.

  • Prospective/ concurrent cohort study: The outcome has not occurred at the time the investigation begins. It will start in present and continue in the future.
  • Retrospective/ historical cohort study: The outcome has already occurred at the time the investigation begins. The investigation started in the past and continued till the present.
  • Combination of prospective and retrospective cohort study: Outcome has already occurred at the time investigation begins. The investigation is done from the past to the present. And then from the present, it is followed up in the future, looking at the effects of the outcome.

In a case-control study, progression is from effect to cause as an outcome or disease has already occurred. It uses a control group to compare and support the inference.

A nested case-control study is a case-control study nested in a cohort study. Cases of a disease occurring in a defined cohort are identified. Their controls are those who have not developed the disease by the time the disease occurred in the case. They are also taken from the same cohort.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man working in the smelting industry presents with numbness and tingling in his toes and fingertips, which have slowly progressed to involve the feet and hands symmetrically, in a stocking-glove pattern. There are no other associated neurological deficits. On examination, there is diffuse desquamation of the palms and soles with hyperkeratosis. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a smelting industry worker presenting with neuropathy as well as desquamation and hyperkeratosis of palms and soles is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. The Burtonian line is seen in chronic lead poisoning and is not a feature of arsenic poisoning.

Chronic arsenic poisoning occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore and in the subliming of white arsenic during the manufacture of sheep dips, weed killers, paints, dyes, cosmetics, drugs, etc. Chronic poisoning may follow acute poisoning, especially after recovery from large doses of arsenic.

The clinical features are as follows.

System involved Symptoms
Skin Raindrop pigmentation, melanosis, Bowen disease, facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, alopecia 
Nails Aldrich-Mees Lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails)
Neurologic

Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory and motor polyneuritis (stocking-glove distribution) distal weakness, Encephalopathy, tremors, axonal degeneration
G I tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Hematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and prolonged QT interval, ventricular hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of >100 mg/24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Chemical Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh test
  • Reinsch test
  • Gutzeit test

Dimercaprol is the chelating agent of choice for arsenic poisoning.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing. The child had a cough and cold for the past few days. A lateral x-ray of the neck showed a soft tissue swelling and widening of the prevertebral shadow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the widening of prevertebral shadow on a lateral x-ray of the neck in a 2-year-old child suggests a diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils, causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which leads to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and unilateral swelling on the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The lateral view of the radiograph shows soft tissue swelling and the widening of the prevertebral shadow. The extent of the abscess can be visualised on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Treatment is usually done by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of a large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal oedema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck:

Other options:

Option A - Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils like dental infections, Bezold abscess, petrositis, trauma to the neck, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and swelling of the parotid region. Patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar; paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII and sympathetic chain; and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxaemia. The extent of a lesion can be revealed by a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck. 

The image below shows an enhanced CT scan revealing a large mass involving the left parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces, causing significant airway narrowing.

Option C- Peritonsillar abscess/quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It presents with severe pain in the throat, fever, chills and rigours, and a hot potato voice. There is congestion and swelling of the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula may be pushed to the opposite side. The presence and the extent of the abscess can be identified on a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI. 

The image below shows a peritonsillar abscess.

Option D- Acute epiglottitis is an acute inflammatory condition involving the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoids (supraglottic structures). It is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae and group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. The symptoms have an acute onset with a rapid progression. These include fever, sore throat, dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Indirect laryngoscopy shows oedema and congestion of the supraglottic structure. A lateral x-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis (thumb sign).

Below is an image showing the thumb sign on a radiograph:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the hospital after an episode of painless vaginal bleeding. She was diagnosed with the condition depicted in the image below. In which of the following scenarios can this condition be managed expectantly?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical history of painless vaginal bleeding with the given image points to grade III placenta previa. It can be managed expectantly if there is no active vaginal bleeding.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity, without compromising maternal health.

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa:

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%)
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks
  • No active vaginal bleeding
  • Fetal well-being assured (USG and cardiotocography)

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 weeks
    • Betamethasone 12 mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6 mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest
  • Hb, blood grouping, and urine analysis for protein
  • Inspection of vulval pads
  • Fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics
  • Rh immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women

The pregnancy is carried up to 37 weeks as part of expectant management. During this time, if there is fetal distress or a bleeding episode, then the pregnancy should be terminated immediately.

Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. The classic presentation is painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that often stops spontaneously and then recurs with labor. The bleeding most likely occurs in 3rd trimester and does not lead to a shock-like condition.

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment:

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

 

Indications of definitive management (delivery):

  • Bleeding occurring at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy
  • Patient is in labor
  • Patient is in an exsanguinated state on admission
  • Continuous bleeding of a moderate degree
  • Baby with nonreassuring cardiac status, dead, or known to be congenitally deformed

Cesarean delivery is done when the placental edge is ≤2 cm from the internal os. Vaginal delivery is considered only when the placental edge is > 2-3 cm away.

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird's beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM). 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.  

The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry. The findings are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. 

The image below shows the bird beak appearance of the esophagus on the barium swallow.

 Management is as follows:

  • Heller's myotomy
  • Partial fundoplication
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is mainly done for type 1 and 2. For type 3, it is done if there is recurrence after surgery. 

    In this procedure, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created; through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided.

    The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 

 Other options:

Option A: NOTES - Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery - It helps access the peritoneal cavity or the abdominal cavity through the gastrointestinal tract, without incising the anterior abdominal wall. It is in the experimental stage and is proposed to replace laparoscopic appendicectomy or cholecystectomy. 

Option B: SILS - Single incision laparoscopic surgery - It is also known as 'scarless’ surgery. It has recently been applied in recent times for gallbladder removal or complex biliopancreatic procedures to minimize the invasiveness of the surgery. 

Option D: ROSE -  Restorative obesity surgery endoscopy helps restore the stomach pouch and size of the outlet in patients who have undergone gastric bypass to help them regain back the weight. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP

Normal peristalsis
