DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: A 60-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling is reducible in the neck and increases in size on coughing and performing the Valsalva maneuver. The given presentation is due to an enlarged diverticulum in ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests laryngocele, and it occurs due to the abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx).

Ventricle/Sinus of the larynx:

It is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds. The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane, which starts from the anterior part of the ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When abnormally enlarged and distended, the saccule may form a laryngocele—an air-containing sac that may present in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. Laryngocele in adults may be associated with carcinoma. 

CT scan helps in assessing the extent of the lesion.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization, and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

 

Other options:

Option A: The vestibule is the upper portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the laryngeal inlet and the vestibular folds. It is related to the posterior surface of epiglottis anteriorly, aryepiglottic folds laterally, and the anterior surface of arytenoids posteriorly.

Option C: The infraglottic larynx (subglottic space) is the lower portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. Histologically, it is the transition zone between the stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords and the respiratory epithelium of the trachea.

Option D: Rima glottidis (glottis) is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity measuring 24 mm in men and 16 mm in women anteroposteriorly. It is present between the two vocal cords. Anterior two-thirds of the glottis, known as phonatory glottis, is formed by membranous cords, while the posterior one-third, known as respiratory glottis, is formed by the vocal processes of arytenoids.

The image given below shows the glottis.

Related Pearl: Sites and subsites of the larynx (AJCC Classification)

Sites

Subsites

Supraglottis

Suprahyoid epiglottis

Infrahyoid epiglottis

Arytenoids

Aryepiglottic folds with the corniculate and cuneiform cartilages

False/Ventricular cords

Glottis

Subglottis

Image :  A top view of the larynx (seen with a mirror).

questions.text: A nutritionist is studying the blood levels of various lipoproteins. One of the samples shows elevation of LDL and total cholesterol levels. Which of the following might be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia shows increased levels of LDL and total cholesterol.

Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial hypercholesterolemia occurs due to a defect in LDL receptors. It is an autosomal dominant condition. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and total cholesterol rise. Clinical features include the presence of tendon xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and coronary heart disease.

LDL receptors (apo B100 and apo E) are expressed on multiple types of cells. They are expressed when the cell needs cholesterol for metabolic needs. LDL molecule binds to this receptor and is endocytosed. 

It is a tightly regulated step and involves PCSK9. Therapy targeting PCSK9 has been developed to control the blood levels of LDL.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A young man was brought to the casualty ward following a road traffic accident. He gives a history of having sustained a dashboard injury. On examination, his right lower limb is flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated. Which of the following is not a radiological finding seen in this condition?

choices.text: Femoral head appears smaller than normal
Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view

questions.solution:
The given history of dashboard injury and the examination finding of the right lower limb being in a flexed, adducted, and slightly internally rotated posture suggests posterior hip dislocation. Prominent lesser trochanter on anteroposterior view is not a radiological sign seen in this condition. 

Posterior dislocation of the hip occurs when the knee sustains a force injury. It occurs commonly after dashboard injuries.

Patients present with pain, swelling, history of severe trauma, and deformity. The deformity usually seen is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. It is also associated with the shortening of the leg.

Radiological findings in posterior hip dislocation:

  • Femoral head is displaced above and behind the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen
  • Shenton's line will be broken 

Complications associated with posterior hip dislocation:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans

Treatment includes the reduction of dislocation as soon as possible. If not done within 6 hours, it could lead to osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis. Closed reduction of the dislocation should not be attempted if there is an associated femoral neck fracture.

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: During a murder trial, the suspect is accused of placing one lathi stick across the back of the victim's neck and another across the front. They then tied both ends of the lathi sticks with a rope and squeezed the victim to death. What is this type of strangulation called?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation described in the above clinical scenario is Bansdola. 

In Bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the center of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, rib fractures, and interferes with respiration. 

Other options:

Option A- Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B- Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garrotting was an official method of judicial execution.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garrotting is shown below.

Option D- Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing the chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Below is the image showing burking.

questions.text: In a patient with STEMI, nuclear stress test revealed poor blood supply to the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum. Which of the following blood vessels is most likely to be blocked?
questions.solution:
The anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum is supplied by the left coronary artery. Hence, this artery is most likely blocked.

The right coronary artery distribution supplies:

  • Right atrium
  • Right ventricle (except a small region to the right of the anterior interventricular groove)
  • A variable part of the diaphragmatic aspect of the left ventricle
  • Posteroinferior 1/3rd of the interventricular septum
  • Part of the left atrium
  • The conduction system, as far as the proximal parts of the right and left crura

The left coronary artery distribution supplies:

  • Left atrium
  • Left ventricle
  • A narrow strip of the right ventricle
  • The anterior 2/3rd of the interventricular septum

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, pirfenidone is the least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

Pirfenidone is a growth factor inhibitor. It inhibits growth factors involved in connective tissue proliferation.

Pirfenidone is used to manage acute exacerbations of pulmonary hypertension and to slow the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. Another drug with the same mechanism and use is nintedanib.

Side effects of pirfenidone predominantly involve the gastrointestinal system, nervous system, and skin. They present as nausea, diarrhoea, dizziness, fatigue, photosensitivity, and rash. 

Important drugs causing pulmonary fibrosis:

Antimicrobial agents
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Nitrofurantoin
  3. Amphotericin B
Anti-inflammatory drugs
  1. Aspirin
  2. Gold
  3. Infliximab
  4. Penicillamine
Cardiovascular agents
  1. ACE-inhibitors
  2. Amiodarone
  3. Flecainide
  4. Procainamide
  5. Hydrochlorothiazide
Chemotherapeutic agents
  1. Bleomycin
  2. Busulfan
  3. Mitomycin-C
  4. Cyclophosphamide
  5. Doxorubicin
  6. Melphalan
  7. Methotrexate
Others
  1. Bromocriptine
  2. Methysergide
  3. Sirolimus
  4. Talc

questions.text: A patient who has dental caries develops an earache. Which of the following nerves is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain from dental caries is referred to the ear via the auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Otalgia refers to pain in the ear. It can be due to local causes, referred causes, or psychogenic.

The ear receives nerve supply from multiple nerves, which also supply adjacent areas of the head and neck region. Thus, conditions causing pain in the adjacent areas can also cause pain in the ear. This is termed referred otalgia. 

Referred otalgia is mediated by the following nerves:

Auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve (V nerve):

  • Dental - impacted teeth, caries, Costen syndrome
  • Oral cavity - ulcerative or benign lesions of tongue and oral mucosa
  • Temporomandibular joint - osteoarthritis, bruxism, dislocation, dentures
  • Sphenopalatine neuralgia

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (IX nerve):

  • Oropharynx - lesions of the palate, and tonsil including the tonsillar pillars
  • The base of tongue - tuberculosis or malignancy
  • Eagle's syndrome - elongated styloid process

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (X nerve):

  • Lesions of esophagus
  • Lesions of larynx

Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3 nerve)/Lesser occipital nerve (C2 nerve):

  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Caries spine
  • Spinal lesions

The image attached below sums up the same.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing Doppler ultrasonographic assessment for varicose veins. When the probe was placed inferior to the inguinal crease, the sign shown in the below image was seen on the transverse view in the B-mode. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The sign in the image given above is the Mickey mouse sign, which represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels.

The Mickey mouse sign is seen on the transverse B-mode of USG.

It includes 

  • Great saphenous vein (GSV),
  • Common femoral vein (CFV), and
  • Common femoral artery (CFA)

Normally, the GSV and CFV lie medial to the common femoral artery, which gives rise to the sign.

Mickey mouse in medicine:

  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on antenatal ultrasound, due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits in anencephaly
  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on MRI in progressive supranuclear palsy
  • The Mickey Mouse sign also represents the configuration of the portal triad - the portal vein, common bile duct, and the hepatic artery on biliary ultrasound.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied up in a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue.

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur if the insemination is successful?
questions.solution:
The implantation of the blastocyst in the uterine cavity occurs 6–7 days after fertilization.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Blastocyst starts to establish contact with the uterine wall
  •  Adhesion: Increase in the physical interaction between the blastocyst and the uterine epithelium
  •  Invasion: Syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts penetrate and invade the endometrium

Prior to implantation, the endometrium is primed with estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum. This uterine receptivity is maximal from the 20th to 24th days of the endometrial cycle. Failure of embryo transfer during this time period may result in repeated implantation failure in IVF patients. 

Adherence of the blastocyst to the uterine cavity is a result of interaction between the cell-surface receptors at the implantation site and the blastocyst receptors. 

Related Pearl: Timeline of Various Events Occurring during the Pre-embryonic Phase Development (1st two weeks)

Time after Fertilization

Event

< 24 hrs

Zygote is formed; cleavage begins immediately

2–3 days

5–8 cell stage

3–4 days

Stage of compaction and formation of morula with 16 cells

4–5 days

5–6 days

Zona pellucida disappears

6–7 days

questions.text: Your physiology laboratory partner is being examined during a cardiac system practical. Her heart rate is 80 beats/min and her BP is 100/70 mmHg measured in the supine position. Her heart rate increases to 90 beats/min on standing. Which of the following must have prompted the increase in heart rate?
questions.solution:
The decrease in venous return is the likely initial event to have prompted an increase in heart rate.

When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output. Reduced cardiac output leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors. As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed, leading to increased heart rate.

 Baroreceptors are mechanoreceptors receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels.

  • Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  • Afferents
    • Carotid sinus- a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN)– the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor- a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN)– aortic depressor nerve
  • Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (nucleus tractus solitarius)
  • Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient complains of a burning sensation in both legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling, and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles." Which of the following drugs is used in the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has painful diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the drugs used in the first-line treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as a burning, excruciating, stabbing, or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: At a screening camp for coronary heart disease, four individuals are identified as having certain risk factors. Who among them is at the lowest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person with type B personality
An obese person with sedentary lifestyle
A person with type A personality

questions.solution:
A person with a type B personality has the least risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD). Patients with a type A personality, obesity, sedentary lifestyles, and/or a history of diabetes mellitus are at a greater risk of developing CHD.

Type A personality is associated with competitiveness, restlessness, hostility, and a sense of urgency or impatience. These individuals are more prone to CHD than the Type B personality which is calmer, and more philosophical.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are modifiable and non-modifiable:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol level
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Atherosclerosis

Nonmodifiable (constitutional):

  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Family history
  • Increasing age
  • Male gender

Modifiable:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

Additional risk factors:

  • Inflammation 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] 
  • Elevated plasminogen activator inhibitor 1
  • Type A personality

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with itching and a rash on his torso. He also complains of a chronic cough with sputum production and mucoid diarrhea. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. Blood investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia and raised serum IgE levels.  Larva currens is suspected. What is the preferred treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple erythematous tracts in the skin is suggestive of larva currens caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. The preferred treatment for this condition is ivermectin.

S. stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. It has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil by feeding on bacteria. 

Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. From here, they enter the venous circulation and travel to the right side of the heart and the lungs. Within the lungs, they traverse the capillaries, enter the larynx, migrate up, and are swallowed in the pharynx. Ultimately, they end up in the gastrointestinal tract. 

The female worms lay eggs in the mucosa leading to the release of rhabditiform larva. The larvae then migrate to the lumen of the intestine and are released in feces. They may transform into filariform larvae while transiting through the gastrointestinal tract which then penetrates the mucosa leading to autoinfection. 

The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

Clinical manifestations can be grouped as follows: 

  • Cutaneous manifestations: 
    • Dermatitis is characterized by pruritus and erythema. This occurs at the site where the larvae penetrate the skin. 
    • Larva currens or racing larvae are characterized by multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae
  • Pulmonary manifestations are characterized by bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma. 
  • Intestinal manifestations are characterized by mucoid diarrhea, protein-losing enteropathy, and paralytic ileus. 
  • Hyperinfection occurs in immunocompromised individuals due to extensive autoinfection and worm load. 

Diagnosis of Strongyloides infection is by the wet mount of stool showing rhabditiform larvae or aspirates of sputum, jejunum, or duodenum. Peripheral eosinophilia and IgE may be raised. 

The image given below shows the rhabditiform larvae.

Treatment involves ivermectin (200 mcg/kg/day for 2 days) or albendazole (400 mg/day for 3 days).

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode

questions.text: A young boy presented with the finding seen in the image given below. Which of the following is not true regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is associated with malabsorption syndromes.
It is characterized by perifollicular hyperkeratosis and keratotic papules with a central keratotic plug.
Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.solution:
The image above shows phrynoderma or toad skin. All the statements mentioned above are true about phrynoderma, except that corticosteroids form the mainstay of treatment.

Phrynoderma is predominantly associated with a deficiency of vitamin A. Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5-15 year age group. Earlier thought to be purely due to vitamin A deficiency, it has now been associated with other nutritional deficiencies, including malnutrition and deficiencies of B complex, riboflavin, vitamin C, vitamin E, and essential fatty acids.

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with the following:

• Liver cirrhosis
• Malabsorption syndromes
• Anorexia nervosa
• Alcohol abuse
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery

It manifests as groups of papules, each one around 3–4 mm in diameter, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas, but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their vitamin A levels measured. 

Oral administration of vitamin A is preferred over parenteral therapy. The dosage, in children aged 8 years or above and adults is 1,00,000 units daily for 3 days, followed by 50,000 units daily for 2 weeks, and then 10,000 units daily for 2 months, until liver storage is adequate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve (DRC)?

choices.text: Drug D is the least potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug  B is the least potent

questions.solution:
The greater the shift of the curve towards the left, the more potent the drug is. Hence, drug D is the least potent.

Potency: It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. The greater the shift of the curve towards the left side, the higher is potency of the drug. This is because the desired response is being achieved at a lower drug dose.

Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B is the most potent, and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy: It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C, and D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with pain in the foot after she tripped while walking on the road and twisted her ankle inwards. On examination, there is tenderness over the prominence at the base of the fifth metatarsal bone. The x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Above-ankle cast and immobilization for 6 months
Conservative management with rest, followed by early mobilization

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray findings are indicative of a fracture involving metaphysis of the 5th metatarsal, which is known as a Jones fracture. The treatment of choice is conservative management with rest, followed by early mobilization.

Mechanism of injury: Forced inversion of the foot (pothole injury) may cause avulsion of the base of the fifth metatarsal, with pull-off by the peroneus brevis tendon or the lateral band of the plantar fascia. The peroneus brevis tendon and the lateral band of plantar fascia insert onto the base of the fifth metatarsal.

Proximal avulsion fractures can usually be treated symptomatically with initial rest for 6-8 weeks and support with a plaster cast, but with early mobilization and return to function. 

Note: A relative watershed area of blood supply is present in the fifth metatarsal at the junction between the diaphysis and metaphysis and is most susceptible to injury.

Other options:

  • Open reduction and internal fixation are usually done if the patient's functional demands and expectations with respect to sports and activities are high.
  • Above-ankle cast and immobilization for 6 months are not warranted for Jones fracture.
  • Immediate return to function can worsen the symptoms and would not be beneficial for the patient.

Other fractures that are seen around the base of the 5th metatarsal are shown in the image below:

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient with a demyelinating disease presents with a  cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) report showing the presence of oligoclonal bands. His MRI brain is given below. His laboratory investigations showed positivity for the John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody. Which of the following drugs is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a demyelinating disease with oligoclonal bands in CSF and the image showing periventricular and callosal lesions called Dawson's finger sign is suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Natalizumab is not recommended for this patient.

Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin. It is highly effective and reduces the attack rate thus improving the severity of the disease (both clinical and MRI). Natalizumab is given as an injectable preparation. 

The major concern associated with natalizumab is the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is also a life-threatening condition developed from the JC virus infection. The risk of developing PML is higher in patients taking natalizumab associated with JC antibody positive. Therefore, natalizumab is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients.

Other options:

Option A- Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate inhibitor. It reduces the attack rate and improves the disease severity in multiple sclerosis. It is given as oral preparation. The patients on fingolimod are at risk of developing macular edema and disseminated varicella-zoster infection.

Option B- Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. It is given as oral preparation. The adverse effect includes Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It has teratogenicity and is considered a category X drug. 

Option C- Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells. It is given as an intravenous preparation. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancies like breast cancers and infusion reactions.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who is on metformin presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On evaluation, her blood sugar levels are within normal limits. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis report is given below. What is the most likely cause for her ABG findings?
  • pH - 7.24
  • HCO3 - 16 mEq/L
  • PaCO2- 35 mmHg
  • Sodium levels - 130 mEq/L
  • Chloride levels - 94 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the above ABG findings is lactic acidosis.

This patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This is most probably due to lactic acidosis due to the history of metformin treatment.

Inference from the given question stem:

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.24, which indicates acidosis. (normal range: 7.35-7.45)

Step 2: Bicarbonate level in this patient is 16 mEq/L, which is decreased. This signifies the deficiency of the base. Hence, this is metabolic acidosis. (normal range: 22-26 mmHg)

Step 3: PaCO2 level in this patient is 35 mmHg, which is normal. (normal range 35-45 mmHg)

Step 4: Anion gap calculation:

Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl-+HCO3-)

=130 - (94+16)

=20, which is a high anion gap

Other causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Ethanol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Methanol poisoning 
  • Renal failure
  • Propylene glycol poisoning

Other options:

Option A- Diabetic ketoacidosis results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis associated with elevated levels of ketone bodies and hyperglycemia (serum glucose level >17 mmol/L or 300 mg/dL). This cannot be the cause in this patient as the serum glucose levels are within normal limits.

Options C and D- Diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis type 1 results in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset fever, chills, headache, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a history of rodent infestation at his farm. He is diagnosed with a disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image below. Identify the type of zoonosis and the type of biological transmission in this disease.
questions.solution:
The given image above is of a rat flea, which transmits plague bacilli. The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Zoonoses: These are diseases and infections that are naturally transmitted between other vertebrate animals and man.

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/ fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclozoonoses

Require more than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle and no invertebrate host

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Metazoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which the infective agent develops/multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Saprozoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

Biological transmission in vector-borne diseases:

  • Propagative - The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form. e.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.
  • Cyclo-propagative - The agent changes in form and in number. e.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.
  • Cyclo-developmental - The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication. e.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.
  • Transovarial - The infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny. e.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.
  • Transstadial - The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next. e.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Plague is a zoonotic disease. The plague bacillus is a natural parasite in rodents and the infection is transmitted amongst them by rat fleas. In the flea, the bacilli multiply and block the proventriculus. When such a blocked flea bites another rodent, the blood, mixed with the bacteria is regurgitated into the bite, transmitting the infection.

When a diseased rat dies (rat fall), the fleas may bite human beings, causing the plague, which usually manifests as sudden onset of fever and painful lymphadenopathy. Several species of fleas act as vectors. 

Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms:

Bubonic plague is the most common variety. It is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite.

Pneumonic plague occurs when bubonic plague spreads to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague, and an infected person may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans.

Septicemic plague occurs when the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male patient came with complaints of wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough for the past 3 weeks. The cough is productive, with brown mucus plugs. He is a known case of bronchial asthma since childhood. Auscultation reveals widespread expiratory wheeze. Chest x-ray of the patient had the characteristic finding shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs can be given in this condition?

Laboratory findings:

  • IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of cough, shortness of breath, x-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance with peripheral eosinophilia, and IgE more than 1000 ng/mL is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Among the given options omalizumab can be used for ABPA.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE.

Low-dose glucocorticoids (prednisolone 7.5–10 mg) is considered for the prevention of progressive lung damage in ABPA and suppression of the immunopathological responses. Itraconazole 400 mg/day can be used to facilitate a reduction in oral glucocorticoid.  

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with long-standing asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes, an expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly in the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus termed as finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is seen occasionally

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of

  • Serum IgE >1000 ng/mL
  • Positive skin prick test in response to Aspergillus fumigatus extract
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol. Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of S. anacardium. Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol. 

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis. It is a toxalbumin or phytotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis by affecting the ribosomal RNA polymerase. The seeds are flat to oval-shaped and have dark brown markings (shown below). It is a chemical warfare agent.

 

Option C: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius. The seeds are egg-shaped, scarlet in color, and have a black spot at one end (shown below). On ingestion, it causes gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tachycardia, and circulatory collapse. Injecting the active substance can mimic viperine snakebite. Rarely, it may lead to tetanic convulsions. 

The seeds of A. precatorius are decocted and mixed with datura, opium, onion, spirit, and water to form a paste. From this, small sharp needles called suis are made. They are used for hunting animals and even for homicide purposes.

 

Option D: Calotropin is one of the active principles of Calotropis. The toxic parts of the plant are the stem, branches, leaves, and milky white latex (Madar juice). When applied locally, it can mimic bruises, and form pustules and vesicles. In the eyes, it can lead to conjunctivitis. On ingestion, it causes abdominal pain, vomiting, mydriasis, and tetanic convulsions and can eventually lead to collapse and death.

It is shown in the image below.

 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fatigue, increased urination, and abdominal pain since the previous night. She was recently treated for severe diarrhea. Fingerstick blood glucose measurement shows a glucose level of 480 mg/dL. The serum potassium level is 4.5 mEq/L. Which of the following statements is true for this condition?
  1. Kussmaul breathing is seen.
  2. ABG analysis shows elevated bicarbonate levels.
  3. Total-body potassium deficit observed.
  4. Serum lipase level is elevated.
  5. Immediate bolus of short-acting regular insulin (0.1 units/kg) IV must be given.

 ABG - Arterial blood gas
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient with fatigue, abdominal pain, and hyperglycemia is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. True statements about diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) are 1, 3, and 5.

This young patient has a medical history significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus and a recent diarrheal illness that acts as a trigger for the hyperglycemic complication of DKA. Other triggers include suboptimal insulin dosing, pregnancy, and use of illicit drugs.

DKA is a complication of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus common in type 1 diabetes mellitus but can also occur in type 2 DM. It occurs in the setting of absolute or relative insulin deficiency along with glucagon excess leading to extreme hyperglycemia.

Clinical features include severe nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and severe volume depletion. Signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor on the patient’s breath, tachycardia, dehydration, and hypotension. 

The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL
  • Ketosis or ketones in the urine
  • Metabolic acidosis with pH <7.4 and HCO3 <15 mEq/L
  • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis

Despite a total body potassium deficit, the serum potassium level at presentation may be mildly elevated (4.5 mEq/L), secondary to acidosis and volume depletion. Due to acidosis and volume depletion, intracellular potassium ions are displaced to the extracellular compartment secondary to the intracellular shift of the hydrogen ions. This results in a total body potassium deficit.

Treatment involves the administration of short-acting regular insulin first as an IV bolus of 0.1 units/kg, followed by 0.1 units/kg/h of continuous IV infusion.  

Note: Since serum amylase levels may be raised in DKA, pancreatitis is a possible differential diagnosis, especially when there is accompanying abdominal pain in the patient. It can be ruled out by measuring serum lipase levels (specific for pancreatitis), which are normal in DKA. 

Criteria for resolution of ketoacidosis:

  • Blood glucose <200 mg/dL, and
  • Two of the following criteria:
    • Serum bicarbonate level ≥15 mEq/L
    • Venous pH >7.3
    • Anion gap ≤12 mEq/L

questions.text: The most abundant subclass of IgG present in the serum is ______.
questions.solution:
IgG1 is the most abundant subclass of IgG present in serum. It represents about 65% of the total IgG.

IgG antibody has 4 subclasses. It plays a role in immunological reactions such as complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of viruses and toxins. IgG1 has the highest concentration in the serum, while IgG4 has the lowest concentration. 

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta, especially the IgG1 and IgG3 subclasses. 

IgG2 is directed against polysaccharide antigens and hence is important in the host defense mechanism against encapsulated bacteria.

IgG3 is an effective activator of the complement, whereas IgG4 does not activate complement due to its compact structure.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A patient was administered rocuronium as a muscle relaxant during surgery. However, the surgeon was able to finish the procedure sooner than expected. What specific reversal agent will you use?
questions.solution:
The specific reversal agent that can terminate the action of rocuronium is sugammadex.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Rocuronium at higher doses can be used in rapid sequence intubation. However, the only downside is its long duration of action. This obstacle can be overcome by sugammadex, which will reverse its effects.

Other options-

Option (A): Neostigmine reversal requires a baseline twitch response. Sugammadex, on the other hand, can be administered at any depth muscle blockade, thereby making it more useful.

Option (C) and Option (D): Atropine and glycopyrrolate are administered along with anticholinesterases pre-operatively to reduce muscarinic side effects like bradycardia. They are not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A month-old neonate was brought to the outpatient department with fever, poor feeding, and lethargy. His respiratory rate was high, and you suspect pneumonia. What respiratory rate would be defined as fast breathing in this child?
questions.solution:
A neonate or an infant within 2 months of age presenting with a respiratory rate of more than 60 breaths/minute is considered to have fast breathing.

If the infant has >60 breaths/minute, it is advised to recount, as respiration in infants is usually erratic, and some infants may stop breathing for a few seconds, and rapidly breathe later.

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with a cough or difficulty breathing:

  • Respiratory rate: It distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. A child is said to have rapid breathing if he/she has
    • >60 breaths/minute for infants aged less than two months.
    • >50 breaths/minute for infants aged 2 months to 12 months.
    • >40 breaths/minute for children aged 12 months to 5 years of age.
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Indicates severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission

According to the recent WHO guidelines, children with fast breathing with/without chest indrawing are classified as having "pneumonia."

Danger signs of severe pneumonia:

  • Not able to drink
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: An immunologist has arranged a series of tubes for an experiment on precipitation reaction. The tubes contain equal amounts of antiserum, while increasing quantities of antigen are added from left to right. One of the middle tubes shows maximum precipitation. What is the phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube is called the prozone phenomenon. Here, antibodies are in excess compared to antigens leading to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

  • The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test (tubes on the left side in the question stem).
  • In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. (tube in the middle in question stem)
  • Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation (tubes on the right side in the question stem).


Prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Flocculation: It is a type of precipitation reaction in which the precipitate remains suspended as flocculus, instead of sedimenting.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about surfactant.

choices.text: Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio of ≥1 is considered normal.
Shake test is used to assess the presence of surfactant.

questions.solution:
Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio of ≥2 is considered normal (not ≥1).

Surfactant acts by reducing the surface tension of water. It is produced by type 2 pneumocytes.

Components of surfactant:

  • Phospholipid - Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)/ dipalmitoyl lecithin is the major component. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol - minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Clinical relevance:

  • Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:
    • Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio, i.e. L/S ratio of ≥2 is considered normal.
    • Shake test/ Bubble test/ Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
    • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has an absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF, which is involved in the clearance of surfactant

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon is taking a class on various tendon repair surgeries, by using cadaveric specimens. While demonstrating a procedure on the muscle marked X, he points to a nerve that is in close proximity to this muscle. He emphasizes that damage to this nerve would result in poor function of the marked muscle and would affect the eversion of the sub-talar joint. Which nerve is the surgeon talking about?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the peroneus longus (principle evertor of the foot) since it lies in the lateral compartment. It is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve. Damage to the superficial peroneal nerve, the nerve in close proximity to this muscle, would result in loss of eversion at the sub-talar joint.

The anterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

Contents: 

  • Tibialis anterior
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Peroneus tertius 

The lateral compartment of the leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

The posterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the tibial nerve. 

Contents:

  • Gastrocnemius
  • Soleus
  • Plantaris
  • Popliteus
  • Flexor hallucis longus
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • Tibialis posterior

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen for the last 20 years due to back pain. The following findings are seen in his peripheral smear. Which of the following is likely to be been seen in this patient?

TIBC - Total iron-binding capacity

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia. In iron-deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding as seen in this patient, where it presents as anemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron-deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and, chronic blood loss. The cause of IDA in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth), and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

The image given below shows koilonychia:

 

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low hemoglobin level and low hematocrit. Serum levels of iron and ferritin are low while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis and, hence, hepcidin is low.

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells

The image below shows a peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells:

 

Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate raise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stains in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral, and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200 mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg of elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight (kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000 mg (for stores).

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy was brought by his parents to screen for thalassemia since both his parents are carriers of the disease. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed, and the result is given below. What is the diagnosis?

X-axis: Time (in min)

Y-axis: Analyte concentration (in %)
questions.solution:
The HPLC results show increased HbA2 and normal HbF values, pointing to a diagnosis of thalassemia trait.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Clinical syndromes of β-thalassemia depending on the genetic defect:

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow
  Major Minor (also called trait)
Genotype

β0/β0, β0/β+, β+/β+ (2 β-thalassemia alleles)

β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele)
Hb
electro-phoresis

HbF: Major Hb, markedly elevated

HbA2: Usually normal to low

HbA: Absent or present in small amounts

HbA2: Increased (4-8%) with an elevated ratio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis

HbF: Normal or slightly increased

A third clinical syndrome of moderate severity is called β-thalassemia intermedia. The genotype in this type includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β0/β+ and does not require regular transfusions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last four days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is true regarding the biochemical test results of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. It is oxidase and catalase-positive.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. It uses pili for adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces to reach the subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days.

The major symptoms include vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

Female patients:

About half the female patients remain asymptomatic. But, patients typically present with urethritis, cervical discharge, pruritus, dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

The ectocervix and vagina are not usually affected in adults as the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci. The acidic pH of vaginal secretions is also protective. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely, peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, with abnormal liver function test results.

Male patients:

  • Acute urethritis
  • Genital discharge: It is mucopurulent that can be described as that resembling the flow of seed (semen).
  • Strictures
  • Water-can perineum: The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses.

Laboratory diagnosis:

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain, which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It is non-sporulating, non-motile and aerobic but may grow anaerobically also. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate N. gonorrheae. 

Treatment:

According to CDC guidelines (2021), treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections is as follows:

  • Weight <150 kg – Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) in a single dose
  • Weight ≥150 kg – Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) in a single dose

Concurrent chlamydial infection must also be treated, unless it has been excluded by molecular testing. First-line drugs used are as follows:

  • Oral azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days (non-pregnant patients only)

The sexual partners of the patient must be treated to reduce the risk of recurrence. Expedited partner therapy refers to the index patient delivering therapy to one's own partners. However, this type of empirical therapy ignores the importance of direct counseling.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Comparison between Meningococci and Gonococci

Properties Meningococcus Gonococcus
Carbohydrates fermented Glucose and Maltose  Only Glucose
Location Both intra- and extracellular Predominantly intracellular 
Spread Respiratory or oral secretions  Sexual or perinatal transmission
Plasmids Rare  Has plasmids that code for drug resistance

Vaccine

Capsule-based polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines available 

(except for Type B - subcapsular antigen-based vaccine is available) 

 No vaccine due to antigenic variation of pilus proteins

Capsule

Present

 Absent

Shape

Lens/half-moon 

 Kidney 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma in a population was found to be 5 times higher in smokers than in non-smokers. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
The attributable risk, in this case, will be 80%.

Let the incidence of bladder carcinoma in non-smokers (non-exposed) be x. Therefore, the incidence in smokers (exposed) will be 5x.

According to the formula, attributable risk (AR) is given as follows:

AR (%) = [(IP exposed - IP non-exposed)/ IP exposed] x100, where IP = Incidence proportion

= [(5x - x)/5x] x 100

= 4x/5x x 100

= 80%

Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A lady was found to have the feature seen in image A, which is characteristic of a certain disease. On further investigations, she was found to have the immunofluorescence pattern seen in image B. Positivity of which of the following antibodies would predict a high risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A showing classical prominent perioral radial furrowing and microstomia and image B showing nucleolar pattern are suggestive of systemic sclerosis. Anti-Scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at high risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features is seen in scleroderma. Initially, the fingers may be puffy and have nonpitting edema. The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly. Severe pruritus, vasospasm, and digital ulceration may be present. 

Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia (fish mouth appearance), perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma have dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux at the level of the esophagus. The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients.

The nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus, representing antibodies against RNA) is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. 

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstitial lung disease.

Other options:

Option A - Anti-U3-RNP (anti-fibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

Option B - Anti-centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
 
Option D - Anti-U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

 

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the criteria used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots
Amine-like odor on adding potassium hydroxide

questions.solution:
Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots is not included in the criteria used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, specifically the lactobacilli. Lactobacilli are responsible for maintaining vaginal pH and reducing the growth of other pathogenic bacteria. In this condition, the number of lactobacilli is reduced, resulting in an increase in the number of pathogenic organisms like Gardnerella vaginalis, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis.

It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH - Potassium hydroxide (whiff test positive)
  • Presence of clue cells (>20% of cells) which are epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.

The images given below shows clue cells:

 

Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or clindamycin cream (2%) applied intravaginally daily at bedtime for 7 days can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots (strawberry cervix) is typically seen in Trichomoniasis, which is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. The clinical features include copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge associated with vaginal irritation. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonas and WBCs are seen on wet mount examination. Single-dose of metronidazole 2 g or tinidazole 2 g is used in the treatment of this infection.

Given below is an image of a strawberry cervix:

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Sexual transmission No Yes No

Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with continuous fever. On examination, pallor and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. The bone marrow picture is shown in the image given below. Which of the following hepatic cells are mainly targeted in this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing macrophages infected with intracellular amastigotes is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani. It affects the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. 

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Though lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, it is rare in India. 

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote, which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote, which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

The illustration given below shows the lifecycle of Leishmania:

 

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, and hepatosplenomegaly, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive; usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis; valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.
