Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with skin findings as shown in the given image presents with low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive dyspnea. Her x-ray image is shown below. Which of the following features is not seen in her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image showing lupus pernio and the chest x-ray showing the garland triad/pawnbroker's sign, is suggestive of sarcoidosis. One of the features of sarcoidosis is non-caseating granulomas. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

There are two syndromes that are associated with the condition:

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is the bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematous-violaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include the following:

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings.

Chest x-ray findings include the following:

  • The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.
  • Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.
  • It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or pawnbrokers sign.

The staging of sarcoidosis is as below:

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis  
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE. 
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following types of rhinitis is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia, along with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment to the affected part. Ointments with antibiotics and steroids can also be used.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinitis caseosa is a condition in which the nose is filled with purulent discharge/cheesy material. It is a unilateral condition mostly affecting males. This condition usually results from chronic sinusitis, where the mucosa of the sinuses becomes granulomatous and the sinuses are filled with cheesy material. Management includes the removal of debris and ensuring good drainage of the sinuses.

Option C: Secondary atrophic rhinitis is a condition when atrophic changes in the nasal cavity occur secondary to specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

questions.text: The contrast media used in the study depicted below is contraindicated in all the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given image is a contrast radiograph of a barium meal. Barium-based contrast media can be used in the case of bowel strictures, but only in small amounts.

Barium-based contrast media:

  • They are preferred for the study of the gastrointestinal tract as they is very poorly soluble and are not absorbed during passage through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • They can cause granulomas and, rarely, fatal reactions on leaking into the mediastinum or peritoneal cavity. Therefore, they are contraindicated when:
    • the integrity of the gut wall is compromised, e.g. suspected aspiration, a fistula between esophagus and lungs, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, and/or
    • there is a history of allergic reactions to barium products.
  • They are used with caution in case of bowel strictures and extensive colitis.
  • Complications: Leakage into the vasculature, worsening of ulcerative colitis inflammation

questions.text: A retired 65-year-old man was found to have a mass in the right lower lobe of the lung on chest x-ray. A  biopsy sample was taken from the mass. The image below shows the findings of histopathological examination and Immunohistochemical staining with calretinin. Which of the following was the most likely profession of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing malignant epithelioid mesothelioma (a neoplasm most commonly associated with asbestos exposure) is most likely suggestive of asbestosis. Hence, the most likely profession of this patient would be an asbestos factory worker.

The histopathological image shows cuboidal and flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. These are strongly positive for calretinin. These features point toward the diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma. The most common cancer associated with asbestosis is lung adenocarcinoma; however, mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. It arises from either the visceral or parietal pleura. Less common sites include the peritoneum, pericardium, tunica vaginalis, and genital tract. 

Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and recurrent pleural effusions. The lung is invaded directly, and metastatic spread may involve the hilar lymph nodes, the liver, and other distant organs. 

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung is ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish-pink tumor tissue.

The image given below shows the gross pathology of mesothelioma:

Microscopically, they are of three types:

  • Epithelial - shows cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma
  • Sarcomatous/mesenchymal- has a histological appearance resembling fibrosarcoma
  • Biphasic/mixed

The image given below shows an epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma.

The image given below shows malignant mesothelioma under immunohistochemical staining with calretinin.

Other options :

Option B: Sandblasters are at increased risk of developing silicosis. Silicosis is associated with the calcification of hilar lymph nodes, which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. Histopathology in silicosis shows whorled collagen fibers. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The image below shows whorled collagen in a silicosis nodule:

 

Option C: Welders are at increased risk of exposure to iron oxide, leading to siderosis.

 

Option D: Coal miners are at increased risk of developing coal workers' pneumoconiosis.  

The image below shows histopathological appearance of coal worker's pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for brain death, except:
questions.solution:
All the options are criteria for brain death, except absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/ spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord function below C1 is intact. 

Clinical criteria for brain death:

  • Coma- Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
  • Absent motor activity- No decerebrate or decorticate posturing
  • Absence of brainstem reflexes- Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea- Absence of spontaneous respiration at  arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60 mmHg

Confirmatory test findings (not mandatory but may assist in diagnosis)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of somatosensory evoked potentials and brainstem evoked potentials 
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion, as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl underwent abdominal ultrasound as a part of the evaluation for stomach ache. She was incidentally found to have an absent uterus and intra-abdominal testes. Clinical examination revealed female external genitalia and breast development appropriate for age but sparse axillary and pubic hair. The karyotype is 46,XY. Which of the following is not preferred as a treatment option in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) and immediate orchidectomy at diagnosis is not a treatment option to manage this condition. Orchidectomy should preferably be performed after pubertal maturation in a patient with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. It is preferably done at 16-18 years.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder in which the androgen receptors are absent, or scanty, or fail to respond to testosterone. As a result, resistance to androgens may be complete, and female external genitalia are found. The individual has a genetic makeup of 46XY but is phenotypically a female. The Wolffian duct fails to develop because of the absence of testosterone receptors. Testes produce Mullerian-inhibiting factors, so the Müllerian system fails to develop. However, the lower portion of the vagina derived from the sinovaginal bulb appears as a dimple of 1–2 cm in length.

AIS can be present in two forms:

  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

In complete AIS, the individual is born as a phenotypically normal female but generally presents with primary amenorrhea. The external genitalia appears normal, with absent or scant pubic and axillary hair. The vagina is shortened and blind-ending with an absent uterus and ovaries. These patients may also present with a history of childhood inguinal hernias, due to the presence of undescended testis in the abdomen or in the inguinal canal. Due to the constant conversion of testosterone into estrogen, these individuals have normal breast development.

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound reveals the absence of ovaries and the uterus.
  • Testosterone > 200 ng/mL
  • Leutinizing hormone level is raised, but follicle-stimulating hormone level is normal.
  • Chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes.

Management:

  • Identify the location of ectopic testis and perform orchidectomy after puberty to prevent malignant degeneration. Malignant transformation usually does not occur until after puberty.
  • Estrogen therapy for the development of the breasts as well as to prevent osteoporosis
  • Surgical vaginoplasty at the time of marriage
  • Absent reproductive function, surrogacy is considered.

In partial AIS, a few receptors do respond to testosterone, whereby the clinical features are variable. Some patients present at birth with ambiguous genitalia, and chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes, while others present at puberty, with lack of virilization in a boy or signs of virilization in a girl with primary amenorrhoea.

The treatment is based on the sex in which the child is reared, psychological behavior, and the amount of virilization. If the child is reared as female, it is best to perform gonadectomy in childhood to avoid virilization. In a boy, testosterone will help.

Given below is an algorithm for the diagnosis of primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characteristics:

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with thiamine deficiency developed lactic acidosis. While on rounds, the senior resident explains the biochemical basis for the development of this condition. He says an important enzyme complex is principally affected. Which of the following is not a component of the enzyme complex being spoken of here?
questions.solution:
The enzyme complex affected in an alcoholic with lactic acidosis is the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex. Pyruvate kinase is not a part of this complex. 

The three enzyme components of the PDH complex:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

Thiamine is a cofactor of the pyruvate dehydrogenase component of the PDH complex. In thiamine deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited. Many alcoholics are thiamine deficient because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamine absorption. 

In the state of thiamine deficiency, there is an impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate then gets converted into lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase. This results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, leading to a state of lactic acidosis. 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is given as follows: Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited:

  • by its end products- acetyl CoA and NADH.
  • when there is adequate ATP available.
  • when fatty acids are being oxidized.
  • by arsenite and mercuric ions that react with the -SH groups. 
  • by a dietary deficiency of thiamine, e.g. chronic alcoholics and beriberi.

Note- Pyruvate kinase is involved in substrate-level phosphorylation to form 2× ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized. The reaction of pyruvate kinase is essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. It is involved in the regulation of glycolysis.

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

Fate of pyruvate

Carries amino group from muscle to liver.

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL) to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Uterine massage after delivery of placenta

questions.solution:
Uterine massage after delivery of placenta is not a part of AMTSL to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

According to revised WHO guidelines 2012, active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) has the following components:

  • Administration of uterotonics within 1 min of delivery.
  • Controlled cord traction and expulsion of placenta.
  • Delayed cord clamping for a minimum of 1 - 3min to reduce anemia in the fetus.
  • Intermittent assessment of the uterine tone for early detection of atony.

These guidelines are specific to the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage.

Uterine massage is not recommended in women who have been administered prophylactic uterotonic. But uterine massage is recommended for treating postpartum hemorrhage.

WHO update in 2017: Administration of a uterotonic remains central to AMTSL. CCT and immediate fundal massage are optional components. 

Recent update: Intravenous oxytocin is preferred to intramuscular oxytocin for the prevention of PPH. This is true only for patients with vaginal deliveries already having intravenous access.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to the emergency with a cardiac arrest and cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following capnographs would be obtained in this case?
questions.solution:
Image B represents the capnographic waveform seen while performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. 

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

Uses of waveform capnography in CPR:

  • Evaluation of the effectiveness of chest compressions (<10 mmHg low EtCO2 suggests poor chest compressions)
  • Identification of return of spontaneous circulation (significant increase to 35–45 mmHg, due to drastic improvement of blood flow to the lungs)

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. It is now the desired investigation for assessing the effectiveness of chest compressions. 

Image A shows rebreathing of CO2, which may occur due to a faulty expiratory valve or an exhausted absorber system. 

Image C shows cardiac oscillations at the end of expiration as flow decreases and the beating heart causes emptying and filling of various parts of the lung with exhaled and fresh air. 

Image D shows malignant hyperthermia.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with lesions as seen in the image below. She gives a history of having primary pulmonary tuberculosis in early childhood. She also gives a history of getting a tattoo over the lateral aspect of her neck 6 months ago. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals. 

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. 

In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, 80% of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

The image given below shows lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Scrofuloderma results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from an underlying contiguous tuberculous focus. It commonly occurs in children. It begins as bluish-red subcutaneous swellings, which ulcerate to form discharging sinuses.

The image given below shows scrofuloderma.

Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It is seen in children with active tuberculosis. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. They are mainly seen on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal limbs.

The image given below shows lichen scrofulosorum.

Option D: Erythema induratum of Bazin is the most commonly reported tuberculid. Patients present with crops of small, tender, and painful erythematous or dusky nodules or plaques on the calves, which may ulcerate. Most patients will have a positive tuberculin test and respond well to antituberculous therapy.

The image given below shows erythema induratum.

Related Pearl: Classification of cutaneous tuberculosis

The classification of cutaneous tuberculosis is based on the mode of acquisition.

Type Pathophysiology AFB

Exogenous

Through broken skin or mucosa
Tuberculous chancre Occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB Multibacillary
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity Paucibacillary

Endogenous

Direct spread from a focus of infection
Scrofuloderma Contiguous spread from affected parts like lymph nodes, joints Multibacillary
Periorificial tuberculosis Autoinoculation at mucocutaneous borders from infected secretions Multibacillary

Hematogenous

Spread from a distant primary focus of TB
Acute cutaneous miliary tuberculosis Occurs in severe disseminated TB Multibacillary
Lupus vulgaris Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity. Mostly hematogenous spread, sometimes exogenous. Paucibacillary
Tuberculous gumma/ abscess Occurs in immunocompromised patients Multibacillary

Tuberculids

Hypersensitivity reaction
Lichen scrofulosorum (micropapular) Hematogenous spread of M. tuberculosis antigens to the skin causes type III hypersensitivity which triggers type IV reaction with granuloma formation Very rarely seen
Papulonecrotic tuberculid
Erythema induratum of Bazin (nodular)

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring water treatment of the city's water sources using the Nalgonda technique. What is the Nalgonda technique used for?

choices.text: Defluoridation of water using lime and alum
Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water. It involves the addition of alum (aluminum sulfate), lime (calcium oxide), and bleaching powder, followed by rapid mixing, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5 mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5 mg/L): This occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6 mg/L): This occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone; these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10 mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous membrane calcification), respectively:

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Controlled super-chlorination is break-point chlorination. Chlorine is added to ammonia in water to produce chloramines, which do not have the same efficiency as free chlorine. If the chlorine dose is increased, there is a destruction of the chloramine causing a reduction in the residual chlorine and the end products formed do not represent any residual chlorine. With a further increase in the chlorine dose, there is a progressive fall in residual chlorine. When the combined chlorines have been destroyed, the residual chlorine begins to increase in proportion to the added dose of chlorine. This is the breakpoint dose. It achieves the same effects as super chlorination, but in a rational manner.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand-picking.

questions.text: A male baby weighing 1.6 kg, born at 34 weeks, has abdominal distension and hematochezia on the 16th day of life. He is apneic, bradycardic, and lethargic. He was fed only with artificial formula milk. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a portal vein gas shadow. What is the stage of disease according to modified Bell's staging criteria?
questions.solution:
Abdominal distension and hematochezia in a preterm baby exclusively fed on formula feed are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The abdominal x-ray finding of portal vein gas shadow is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB, according to modified Bell's staging criteria.

Modified Bell's staging criteria:

  • Stage I - Suspected NEC
  • Stage II - Proven NEC
  • Stage III - Advanced NEC
Stage Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs

I A

Suspected NEC

 Mild
abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool		 Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus
I B IA +
Bright red blood from the rectum		 Same as IA Same as IA
II A

Mildly ill
 Absent
bowel sounds		 Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis,
ileus
II B

Moderately ill
  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+
Metabolic acidosis and thrombo-cytopenia 		  IIA +
portal venous gas, with or without ascites
III A

Severely ill, bowel intact 
 IIB + peritonitis
with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension 		 IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascites 
III B

Severely ill, bowel
perforated
  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumo-peritoneum


Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal x-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

The given x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was diagnosed with atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma. He was started on antibiotic medication but showed no improvement, proving that the drug was ineffective. Which of the following antibiotics would have been used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Beta-lactams antibiotics are ineffective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae as these organisms lack a cell wall. 

Beta-lactam antibiotics are cell wall synthesis inhibitors. They inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase that is required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan chain. Transpeptidases cleave the terminal D-alanine of the peptide chains and form cross-linkages between them. This cross-linking provides rigidity and stability to the cell wall.   

Transpeptidases and other related proteins constitute penicillin-binding proteins (PBP) and are located in the bacterial cell membrane. Beta-lactam antibiotics are bactericidal. This is because bacterias swell and burst due to deficient cell walls when they divide in the presence of beta-lactam antibiotics. Penicillins, cephalosporins, monobactams, and carbapenems are examples of beta-lactam antibiotics.

The resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactam antibiotics can be conferred through one of the following four mechanisms:

  • Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
  • Modification of target penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs)
  • Impaired penetration of drugs to target PBPs
  • Antibiotic efflux

Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks cells wall or even cell wall precursors and hence is resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics. These organisms are bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Mycoplasma is the smallest pleomorphic microorganisms that can thrive in a cell-free medium. They can be grown in fluid or solid media. Colonies typically have a fried egg appearance. They mainly cause pneumonia and genital infections. 

M. pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis.

The image given below shows the chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

Most infections resolve spontaneously but acute infection can be treated with macrolides, tetracyclines and respiratory fluoroquinolones.

questions.text: A young man presented with a growing mass in the neck. It was found to be medullary thyroid carcinoma after workup. Further investigations revealed the presence of pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He mentions that his uncle and his grandfather also had some form of cancer. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has medullary thyroid cancer, along with pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He is likely to be suffering from multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia is characterized by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. It can be MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), or MEN 4.

MEN 1 is associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A nurse is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. These findings denote which of the following?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

In high infectivity chronic HBV, both HBsAg and HBeAg will be present but in low infectivity chronic HBV only HBsAg will be present.

Serological Patterns of Hepatitis B Infection:

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc
Acute HBV +   - +  -  IgM
Window period  - -   - - IgM
Chronic HBV (high infectivity) +  -  +   -  IgG
Chronic HBV (low infectivity) + -  -  +  IgG
Immunized (Vaccination)* -  + -  -   
Immunized (Natural infection) -  +  - -  IgG
Remote past infection -  -  -  -  IgG

 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her friend who reports that the patient eats large amounts of food when she is alone and that food wrappers are often found hidden in her room. Once or twice a week, she vomits after having a large meal. On examination, erosion of teeth enamel is noted. Her BMI is found to be 19. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of binge eating, followed by self-induced vomiting, with normal weight, is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

DSM 5 diagnostic criteria for bulimia nervosa are as follows:

  • A recurrent episode of binge eating characterized by
    • eating relatively a large amount of food in a short span of time
    • lack of control during the episode
  • Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors in order to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, or excessive exercise.
  • This behavior is present at least once a week for 3 months
  • There is fear of becoming fat or wanting to lose weight
  • It does not occur during the periods of anorexia nervosa

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy.

CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, body image, etc. Drugs usually used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A - Anorexia nervosa is diagnosed by the presence of

  • Restriction of food intake, leading to a significantly low body weight
  • Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight.
  • Undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight.

Patients with anorexia nervosa would have weight loss, whereas those with bulimia nervosa would have weight in the normal range.

Option C - Night eating disorder is characterized by the consumption of a large amount of food after an evening meal. Patients generally have a low appetite during the day and have insomnia. They are not overly concerned with their body image and weight, and the amount of food consumed is lower than that consumed during binge eating in bulimia and binge eating disorder. Patients have a high risk for obesity and metabolic syndrome.

Option D - Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating without the recurrent use of compensatory behaviors.

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

 

Anorexia nervosa

Bulimia nervosa

Binge-eating disorder

Avoidance of food

(calorie deficit)

+

-

-

Binge eating

+/-

+

+

(purge/vomit)

 +/-

+

-

BMI

LOW*

NORMAL (18.5–22.9)

HIGH

 *In atypical anorexia nervosa, all the features of anorexia nervosa will be present, but the patient will have normal BMI.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man on multiple antibiotics is suspected to have pseudomembranous colitis. The criteria for the diagnosis of the suspected condition include all, except ______.

choices.text: Detection of toxin A or B in stool
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism
Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)

questions.solution:
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism is not part of the criteria for the diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis.

Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by the gram-positive bacillus Clostridium difficile. It is most commonly associated with the use of antimicrobials like cephalosporin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, and clindamycin.

C. difficile produces two high-molecular-weight exotoxins, toxin A and toxin B, which are involved in the pathogenesis of the condition. Toxin A is an enterotoxin that attaches to gut receptors and may also be cytotoxic, while toxin B is a cytotoxin. The strains can produce either or both toxins. 

The diagnosis is based on a combination of two criteria:
1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)
2. Detection of toxins A and B in stools, detection of toxin-producing C. difficile by NAAT/culture, and visualization of the pseudomembrane in the colon

The endoscopic image given below shows pseudomembranous colitis caused by C. difficile infection:

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can also be used.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with worsening night blindness for the last few years. On further questioning, he reveals that he has been having increasing difficulty doing daily activities like reading and walking without bumping into objects. His fundoscopy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a clinical picture of worsening night blindness, difficulty in walking and reading, with fundoscopic features (bone spicule changes, retinal atrophy, and a peripheral ring of depigmentation) is likely to have retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision, which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Ocular examination reveals normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision will be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy shows bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There is severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataracts, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include the following: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency would lead to xerophthalmia. This also has night blindness and loss of vision. However, retinal involvement would be characterized by yellowish, peripheral dots in advanced cases. 

Option C: Retinal detachment occurs when there is a separation between the neuroepithelium and pigment epithelium of the retina. This can occur due to trauma, neoplasm, or fluid accumulation. It is characterized by light flashes, floaters, and a 'curtain' obscuring the vision. Ophthalmoscopy features depend on the stage. Early stages may not be apparent other than color changes, but later stages may show folds that oscillate on eye movement, grey depressions, and bright summits. 

The image given below shows a shifting fluid sign in exudative retinal detachment.

The following image shows central retinal detachment.

Option D: Acquired syphilis is characterized by anterior uveitis, chorioretinitis, and posterior placoid chorioretinopathy. The retina will have a ground-glass appearance and have vasculitis, leading to scars.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A mother brings her son to the outpatient department after noticing a convergent squint. She recalls that the child's uncle had undergone chemotherapy when he was young. The examination findings are shown in the image given below. Ultrasound shows a small tumor away from the foveola. Which of the following drugs are used in its management?
questions.solution:
The above image shows features of leukocoria and strabismus, which are seen in retinoblastoma. Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide are used in its management.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood and arises from the neurosensory retina. It is associated with germline RB1 mutations, and heritable retinoblastoma patients are predisposed to non-ocular tumors (pinealoblastoma, osteosarcoma, soft tissue sarcoma, and melanoma).

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are characteristic histopathological features.

The most common presentations are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex/ amaurotic cat's eye appearance) and strabismus. Fundus examination is therefore mandatory in all cases of childhood squint.

Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment and comprises intravenous vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. It is given along with focal treatment such as brachytherapy.

Enucleation is indicated when

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina.
  • The optic nerve is involved.
  • Glaucoma is present, and the anterior chamber is involved

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A young man with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. During treatment, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. Findings of a peripheral smear are shown below. The defect in which of the following pathways leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and peripheral smear showing bite cells is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, the enzyme which is involved in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. 

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

G6PD is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative triggers, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

  • Fava beans
  • Infections
  • Drugs such as primaquine, chloroquine, sulfonamides/sulfones, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on ATT. After a year, he develops a sudden decrease in vision of both eyes. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart. He also has pain while moving his eyeballs. On fundus examination, the discs and vessels were normal. What is the most probable drug which can be implicated in this complication?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis, as the patient has a sudden deterioration in his vision, painful extraocular movements, and poor color discrimination. The antitubercular drug, ethambutol can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral. The intensity of the visual difficulty is related to the duration of therapy.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

Ethambutol is used for the treatment of tuberculosis, disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex, and Mycobacterium kansasii infection. It inhibits arabinosyl transferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Since 80% of the drug is eliminated through the kidney unchanged, its dosing should be decreased in renal failure to avoid toxicity. Ethambutol should be given 15-25 mg/kg three times a week, instead of daily in patients with renal failure.

Other side effects are pruritus, joint pain, GI upset, abdominal pain, malaise, headache, dizziness, mental confusion, disorientation, possible hallucinations, and decreased renal excretion of uric acid.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.

Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.

questions.text: A woman requests for the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to be performed at 14 weeks of gestation. Which of the following instruments is most likely to be used?
questions.solution:
The device numbered 3 is the ovum forceps, which is used in dilatation and evacuation (D&E) for MTP in the second trimester.

The ovum forceps have got no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. The absence of the catch minimizes uterine injury if accidentally caught. It prevents the crushing of the conceptus. It is to be introduced with the blades closed, to open up inside the uterine cavity, to grasp the products, and to take out the instrument with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movements facilitate the detachment of the products from the uterine wall.

The ovum forceps are also used to

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Remove the laminated membrane and the daughter cysts during hydatid cyst removal.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of the gallbladder during cholecystectomy.
  • Swab an abscess cavity.

Option A: Cord-holding forceps are typically used to hold spermatic cords.

Option B: The image shows a sponge-holding forceps.

It is used to

  • Clean the skin with a swab dipped in an antiseptic solution during all operations.
  • Remove the laminated membrane and daughter cysts during hydatid cyst removal.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy.
  • Swab an abscess cavity.
  • To hold the cervix during cerclage.


Option D: Pile-holding forceps are used to hold hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: The image below shows changes in body temperature (red line) in response to the changes in the set point of the hypothalamic temperature controller (dotted blue line). At which point does the patient experience chills?
questions.solution:
The patient experiences chills at point 1 in the above image.

When the hypothalamic set point is raised suddenly, the actual body temperature is still at the normal level. The body tries to conserve heat and causes vasoconstriction and the patient feels cold. Then, the patient experiences chill and shivering until the actual body temperature reaches the setpoint.

Once the body temperature reaches the setpoint, the patient feels neither cold nor hot.

When factors such as toxins that caused the setpoint to rise are removed from the blood, the setpoint suddenly falls. This point is called a crisis or flush. At this point, the actual body temperature is still at a higher level. As a result, the patient feels hot, and there is vasodilation. The body loses heat by intense sweating.

questions.text: A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. What is the next course of action by the doctor?

choices.text: Request police officer for a court order
Refuse to carry out medical examination without consent
Wait until the accused gives consent

questions.solution:
The next course of action by the doctor is to perform the medical examination by force. 

Section 53 CrPC deals with the examination of the accused by a doctor using force, in the event that the examination has been requested by a police officer (designation of Sub-Inspector and above). The intention behind such a request must be to procure evidence regarding the offense allegedly committed by the accused [Sec. 53 (1) CrPC]. If the person is accused of rape, a medical examination may be carried out by force (in the event of non-cooperation) by the provisions made by Sec. 53A CrPC.

Whenever the person of a female is examined, the medical examination must be carried out only by, or under the direct supervision of a female doctor [Sec. 53 (2) CrPC].

Such an examination is applicable to the testing of blood, blood stains, semen, swabs, sputum, hair samples, and fingernail clippings. 

Other options:

Consent is mandatory for the examination of a victim in criminal cases. Performing an examination by force or by availing of a court order is not allowed for the examination of a victim.

questions.text: Which of the following ions are present at the maximum concentration in the perilymph of the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Perilymph is similar to extracellular fluid and has high concentrations of sodium.

Perilymph fills the space between the bony and the membranous labyrinth. It communicates with CSF through the aqueduct of cochlea which opens into the scala tympani near the round window. There are two theories regarding the formation of perilymph:

  • It is a filtrate of blood serum and is formed by capillaries of the spiral ligament
  • It is a direct continuation of CSF and reaches the labyrinth via the aqueduct of cochlea.

Endolymph is akin to intracellular fluid and hence high in potassium. It fills the entire membranous labyrinth. There are two theories regarding its flow:

  • Longitudinal: Endolymph from the cochlea reaches the saccule, utricle, and endolymphatic duct and gets absorbed through endolymphatic sac.
  • Radial: Endolymph is secreted by the stria vascularis and also gets absorbed by stria vascularis.

The cochlea consists of a bony canal that makes 2.75 spiral turns around an axis of bone known as the modiolus. A shelf of bone from the modiolus forms a ridge known as the spiral lamina.

The basilar membrane supporting the organ of Corti extends from the spiral lamina to the outer wall of the cochlea. The vestibular membrane runs from the spiral lamina to the outer wall above the basilar membrane. These two membranes divide the bony labyrinth into three cavities:

  • The scala vestibuli, located between the roof of the labyrinth and the vestibular membrane, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.
  • The scala media, located between the vestibular membrane and basilar membrane, contains endolymph.
  • The scala tympani, located between the basilar membrane and the floor of the labyrinth, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text: A diabetic patient was diagnosed to have malignant otitis externa. Which of the following is not a characteristic of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism of malignant otitis externa, which affects elderly uncontrolled diabetics and immunocompromised individuals. P. aeruginosa is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

P. aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus which is:

  • an obligate aerobe (Option A)
  • catalase-positive (Option B)
  • oxidase-positive
  • non-lactose fermenting
  • shows characteristic swarming motility.

They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin (Option D) and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (red), pyomelanin (brown). This is responsible for the formation of blue-green pus in infections and also its appearance on culture media.  It exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples and cause for many hospital acquired infections. 

Diseases caused by P. aeruginosa include:

  • Burns infections (most common cause)
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

The images below show green-colored colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on nutrient agar, and the characteristic swarming motility.

questions.text: A 6-week-old female infant presented with the following appearance and a history of delayed passage of meconium and prolonged jaundice. There is no history of maternal drug intake during the intrauterine period. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Open posterior fontanel is an important indicator for this condition.
Jaundice occurs due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation.
Neurological and cognitive development are refractory to treatment.
TSH levels have a higher sensitivity for screening in this condition.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image (the hypotonic posture, macroglossia, coarse facial features, and umbilical hernia) are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism in the 6-week-old infant. Early diagnosis and treatment with thyroid hormone replacement prevent severe mental retardation and other neurologic complications. 

Screening for children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important; congenital hypothyroidism is known as the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome. A dried blood sample is screened for TSH, usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally. 

Causes of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Goitrous (Palpable goiter):
    • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
    • Iodine deficiency
    • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Non-goitrous (No palpable goiter):
    • Thyroid dysgenesis
    • Thyroid receptor-blocking antibodies
    • Central hypothyroidism

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism become prominent with increasing age. 

  • Hoarse cry, facial puffiness, umbilical hernia, and unexplained hypothermia.
  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Open posterior fontanelle: Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with hematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

6 Ps:  Pot-bellied, Pale, Puffy-faced child with Protruding umbilicus, Protuberant tongue, and Poor brain development

Management: Thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

Related Pearl: Differences between the two types of endemic cretinism

Neurological type Myxedematous type
Goiter  No goiter (USG shows thyroid atrophy)
Euthyroid  Permanent hypothyroidism
Intellectual disability, deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity, and rigidity Intellectual disability, Deaf, coarse facial features, and myxedema.
Normal pubertal development and adult stature Delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development, severe short stature

questions.text: During the dissection class, a professor asks you to name the nerve that innervates the muscle labeled as A. He gives a clue that the nerve will also innervate the rhomboid minor and major. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
Muscle A is the levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. It also supplies the rhomboid major and minor.

The dorsal scapular nerve originates from the C5 root of the brachial plexus, passes posteriorly, and often pierces the middle scalene muscle in the neck. It then travels along the medial border of the scapula and innervates the rhomboid major and minor muscles. It also innervates the levator scapulae along with branches directly from the anterior rami of the C3 and C4 spinal nerves.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is treated with ciprofloxacin for infection in his lungs. Ciprofloxacin acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase. Which of the following enzymatic activities is most directly affected by this inhibition?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase. The gyrase introduces negative supercoils into the DNA to counteract excessive positive supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication due to helicases. 

Normally during replication, DNA gyrase nicks double-stranded DNA and introduces negative supercoils to prevent excessive positive supercoiling of the strands. Fluoroquinolones, by inhibiting DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria), result in the production of damaged DNA. This is finally digested by exonucleases, resulting in bactericidal action.

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, and respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures.

Other options:

Option B: Synthesis of RNA primers is done by the enzyme DNA primase. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme.

Option C: ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA is done by the enzyme helicase. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme.

Option D: Complimentary strand synthesis is done by the enzyme DNA polymerase. Removal of RNA primers and its replacement with deoxyribonucleotides is also carried out by this enzyme. Fluoroquinolones have no action on this enzyme.

questions.text: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. The chest x-ray shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. Which of the following is the enzyme most likely to be involved in the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Pompe's disease. This disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase.

Pompe's disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells.

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and chest x-ray showing cardiomegaly. 

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). 

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen, as shown below.

Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant human acid α-glucosidase (alglucosidase alfa)(Myozyme)

Other options:

Option A- Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease. Patients present commonly at 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- Myophosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle disease leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain, and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Muscle phosphofructokinase deficiency causes Tarui disease (type VII glycogen storage disorder). The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
