questions.text: A male patient presented with discoloration of his nails over the past 6 months. The findings of the physical examination are shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for treating the pathology depicted in this image?

choices.text: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Formation of pores in cell membrane
Inhibition of squalene epoxidase involved in ergosterol synthesis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing the yellowish discoloration of his nails, is suggestive of onychomycosis. Terbinafine is used for the treatment of this condition. The mechanism of action of terbinafine is the inhibition of squalene epoxidase, which is involved in ergosterol synthesis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early-step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases of onychomycosis.

Treatment of onychomycosis:

First-line drug Duration
Oral terbinafine - 250 mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral itraconazole- 400 mg/day for 1 week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months

It is observed that terbinafine, given as one 250 mg tablet daily for adults is somewhat more effective than itraconazole for nail onychomycosis. Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is used as a second-line drug.

Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non-linear superficial onychomycosis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain and stiffness in his hands, knees, and hips. On examination of the hands, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. His knee x-ray is given below. Which of the following joints is likely to be spared in this condition?

choices.text: Intervertebral joints in the lumbar region

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes on examination and reduced joint space on x-ray is suggestive of osteoarthritis. The wrist joint is likely to be spared in this condition.

Other joints that are usually spared in osteoarthritis are the elbow and ankle joints. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

Clinical signs: 

  • Tenderness and inflammation of the joint
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases
  • Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes - palpable nodules in the DIP and PIP joints, respectively (as shown in the image below).

Characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

The image below is an x-ray of osteoarthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fatigue, diarrhea, and weight loss. She reports that the stool is bulky, pale, and foul-smelling. On examination, she has pallor and itchy rashes on her elbows, as shown below. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are noted to be positive. What is the treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy, and the treatment is avoidance of gluten. 

The image shows grouped erythematous papules and vesicles over the elbow. This is dermatitis herpetiformis, the cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease. It generally presents on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. These lesions are intensely pruritic and occur due to IgA deposits in dermal papillae.

Celiac disease is characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase leading to an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria and impairs nutrient absorption. Gluten is commonly found in wheat, barley, and rye. 

It is characterized by:

  • Gastrointestinal manifestations such as bloating and irregular bowel habits. There is villous atrophy in the proximal intestine causing steatorrhea (bulky, pale, and foul-smelling) as well as fluid hypersecretion from crypt epithelium. 
  • Extraintestinal manifestations: 
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis - pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of the limbs
    • DEficiency of vitamins B12 and E causing ataxia and peripheral neuropathy
    • Iron-deficiency anemia
    • Hyposplenism
    • Abnormal liver enzymes
    • Increased risk of malignancy such as enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma and small-bowel adenocarcinoma.
    • Refractory celiac disease 

Screening for celiac disease is done by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. Diagnosis is confirmed by small-intestinal biopsy, which shows characteristic villus blunting and crypt hyperplasia and inflammation. Given below is a histopathological image of celiac disease:

Treatment of celiac disease involves strict avoidance of gluten.

Other options: 

Option B - Broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid are used to treat tropical sprue. It is characterized by chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiency. It occurs in people who live in tropical climates.  To diagnose tropical sprue, malabsorption of two unrelated substances is required. 

Option C - Sulfasalazine is administered in patients with ulcerative colitis. It is characterized by rectal bleeding, diarrhea, passing mucus, and abdominal pain. 

Option D - Opiates are used to treat short bowel syndrome. This will reduce the frequency of passing stool. Short bowel syndrome occurs in people who have had an intestinal resection.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. Two days later, he presented to the hospital with a deviation of eyes, inability to open mouth, and torticollis. What is the first-line management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), inability to open the mouth (trismus), asymmetric position of the head and neck (torticollis) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia. The first-line treatment for antipsychotic-induced acute dystonia is diphenhydramine.

Acute muscular dystonia:

This is an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that occurs due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. 

It occurs most commonly among younger patients and is characterized by muscle spasms involving linguo-facial muscles causing torticollis, locked jaw or trismus, grimacing, tongue thrusting, and oculogyric crisis in severe form.

Treatment:

  1. Anticholinergic agents like benztropine or diphenhydramine, by blocking striatal cholinergic receptors, balance the dopaminergic activity and is given as first-line treatment for dystonia. 
  2. Benzodiazepines (diazepam) antagonizes the excitatory dopaminergic neurons by their GABA agonist action and are used in refractory cases or when anticholinergic use is contraindicated.

Other options:

Option B: Propranolol is used for the management of akathisia.

Option C: Dantrolene is used in the management of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Lorazepam is used for treating anxiety disorders, alcohol withdrawal, and anesthetic medication.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with complaints of fever with chills and chronic fatigue. His peripheral smear showed a garden party appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the peripheral smear showing garden party appearance is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). 

The peripheral smear in CML contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have a garden party appearance or a college girl appearance.

The peripheral smear given below shows a garden party appearance seen in chronic myeloid leukemia.

 

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused due to a translocation mutation that results in the formation of BCR-ABL fusion gene (BCR on chromosome 22 and ABL on chromosome 9). It results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is implicated in CML.

The image given below shows Philadelphia chromosome showing reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation seen in CML.

 

The resulting BCR-ABL translocation results in the activation of tyrosine kinase that signals pro-growth and pro-survival pathways like RAS and JAK/STAT pathways, causing \the proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells.

Patients typically present with a dragging sensation abdomen due to splenomegaly or splenic infarct, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss.

Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 (neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils); blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells, and the platelet count is usually increased.

Bone marrow is hypercellular due to increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors with sea-blue histiocytes (macrophages with wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm).

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction(PCR) are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene. Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in cases of CML.

Sokal scoring is used in assessing the prognosis of this patient.

The prognosis of CML can be assessed on the basis of

  • Age
  • Spleen size
  • Platelet count
  • Percentage of blast cells in the blood

FDA-approved tyrosine kinase inhibitors for the treatment of CML are imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib.

Complications, if left untreated, include the following:

  • Accelerated phase- increased anemia, thrombocytopenia, and basophilia
  • A blast crisis- may transform into acute leukemia (AML/ALL)

Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

questions.text: During morning rounds at the psychiatry ward, you ask a patient with schizophrenia if he has taken his medication. He replies with "Yes, I have taken my medication. The president of America is Joe Biden. My best friend is getting married tomorrow ..." and so on. He continues slowly, and none of the thoughts are related to each other. Which category of thought disorder does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with schizophrenia jumping from one thought to another without relevance indicates derailment/ loosening of associations of thought, which is a disorder of form of thought, as per Fish's classification of thought disorders.

Derailment/ Loosening of associations: A change in the train of thought that is characteristic of schizophrenic thinking. There is no logical sequence to the progression of thoughts, and it manifests as unrelated and unconnected ideas shifting from one subject to another. Patients with this disorder are unable to communicate efficiently.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: The following finding is seen in a 3-day-old newborn. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The palms and soles are usually spared
It is a benign finding in newborns
They are neutrophil laden sterile lesions
Lesions usually persists for only a week

questions.solution:
The lesions seen in the given image indicate erythema toxicum. The false statement is option C as these lesions predominantly contain eosinophils.

Erythema toxicum is a benign finding in a newborn that resolves on its own (Option B). It presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base, predominantly distributed over the trunk and face. The palms and soles are usually spared (Option A). This condition is seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week (Option D). The lesions resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The below finding is seen in which of the following lymphoid tissues?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Hassall's corpuscles; these are seen in the thymus. These are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. They have a central core of degenerated epithelial cells that stain pink. Around this is a circle of epithelial cells that stain pink with hematoxylin and eosin stains. The function of these corpuscles is not clearly understood.

Histology of thymus

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

Structure of a lymph node

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

Structure of spleen (Option A)

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (Options B and C)

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: You notice the senior resident in the surgery outpatient department advising a patient to use the following treatment option for his condition. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows elastic compression stockings. Among the given options, varicose veins is the condition the patient is most likely to have. 

Elastic compression stockings are commonly prescribed for the treatment of chronic venous insufficiency manifesting as venous ulcers or varicose veins. The principal cause of venous insufficiency is venous hypertension. This venous hypertension can be decreased by compression stockings. It helps to push the blood from superficial engorged veins into the deep veins, thus improving the blood-pumping function of the calf muscle. Hence, it decreases edema and improves tissue oxygenation. 

Complications of this therapy include skin excoriation, dryness, skin maceration, and infection. 

Varicose veins are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb. Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound (IVUS). 

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and open surgery.

Other options-

Option A: Raynaud's disease refers to an abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood. Compression will have no effect on these symptoms. Protection from cold can help. 

Option B: Diabetic foot also occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy and atherosclerosis of small arteries in the legs and feet. Hence, improving venous circulation with compression stockings will have no benefit in this condition. 

Option C: Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans involves occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. It occurs in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. It is an arterial occlusive disorder, so compression stockings will have no therapeutic effect.

 

 

The image attached below sums up the therapeutic principle behind compression therapy for venous insufficiency-

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic collision. His heart rate is 124 beats/min and BP is 78/56 mmHg on the right arm, and 64/50 mmHg on the left arm. A portable chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum but normal lung and cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of aortic injury. The investigation of choice in this hemodynamically unstable patient is transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). In hemodynamically stable patients, the investigation of choice is CECT or CT angiogram.

Traumatic aortic injuries are commonly seen in deceleration injuries (e.g. road traffic accidents). The most common site of aortic injury is the isthmus, near the attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. 

Clinical features of aortic injuries: 

  • Hypotension
  • Difference in blood pressure in bilateral limbs
  • Absent pulse in the unilateral limb
  • Widened mediastinum on chest x-ray

Management

  • Volume replacement: fluid therapy and blood transfusion
  • Permissive hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as esmolol
  • Immediate surgical repair:  
    • Endovascular stenting, or
    • Open surgical repair with Dacron graft

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for alprostadil use?

choices.text: Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for the temporary maintenance of the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates, keeping the ductus arteriosus open. 

Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15 hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome,  and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of ductus arteriosus in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia, and cyanosis. Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates is essential in some congenital heart diseases before corrective surgery is performed, and alprostadil is used for this purpose.

Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, erectile dysfunction, and pulmonary hypertension. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

PGE1 analogs like alprostadil, misoprostol, and rioprostil can also be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

Other options:

Option A: PGF2α analog carboprost is used as an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Option B: Indomethacin a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug is used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus.

Option D: Dinoprostone (PGE2) can be used for the induction of labor.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following are likely to be seen physiologically?

choices.text: Increase in 1,2, and 7; no change in 3, 5 and 6
Increase in 1, 2 and 4; no change in 3, 5 and 7
Increase in 1 and 7; no change in 2 and 4
Increase in 3, 5 and 6; no change in 1 and 2

questions.solution:
Tidal volume and inspiratory capacity (1 and 7) increase physiologically during pregnancy, while inspiratory reserve volume and vital capacity (2 and 4) remain unchanged.

Changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text:
A child was brought to the primary health center for vaccination. The parents informed the medical officer that the child had a history of egg allergy. Which of the following vaccines can not be given to the child?
  1. Yellow fever
  2. Japanese encephalitis
  3. Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  4. Influenza
  5. Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, yellow fever and influenza vaccines cannot be given to a child who has an egg allergy.

Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are prepared in hen's egg tissues. Hence, they cannot be given to a patient with a history of anaphylactic reactions following egg ingestion. However, vaccine viruses propagated in chicken fibroblast cells like measles or MMR vaccines can be given.

questions.text: Which of the following shows septate hyphae as depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The microscopic image above shows septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles and a typical conidiophore is characteristic of Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is used for management.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option A: Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image given below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores:

 

Option B: Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Microscopy on Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.

The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

 

Options C: Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image given below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A man complains of bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine has turned black on standing, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with urine that turns black on standing and blackish discoloration of soft tissues (oochronosis) is characteristic of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase). The homogentisic acid in these patients is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-colored alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage, and this phenomenon is called ochronosis.

In the following images, A shows normal urine and B shows urine from patients with alkaptonuria

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. The findings of lymph node biopsy are shown in the image below. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Laboratory findings are given below. Which translocation is responsible for this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10 g/dL

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image and laboratory findings are suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare subtype of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is usually identified by a translocation of the CCND1 gene. It presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

Clinical features:

  • Extensive painless lymphadenopathy
  • B-symptoms like fevers, night sweats, and weight loss symptoms
  • Splenomegaly-related discomfort
  • Blood count abnormalities due to bone marrow involvement
  • Symptoms related to extranodal organ involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, liver, and bone marrow
  • Mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions called lymphomatoid polyposis

Histopathological features:

  • There is a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft nuclear contours.
  • The nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting nodular mantle cell lymphoma:

 

Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19 to CD22.

The prognosis is poor with a median survival of 3 to 4 years.

Other options:

Option B: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. Patients usually will be adolescents or young adults presenting with extranodal masses. It may sometimes present as leukemia.

Option C: t(11;22) is seen in Ewing sarcoma. It is a bone tumor presenting with swelling and tenderness over the site. Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance

Option D: t(14;18) is seen in follicular lymphoma. They present with multiple areas of painless lymphadenopathy. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes would show nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Tilley’s forceps.

Tilley's forceps are used for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

Other options:

Options A and B: Walsham forceps and Asch’s forceps are used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

  • Walsham forceps is mainly used to reduce bone fracture.

 

  • Asch’s forceps are mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

 

Option D: Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues.

questions.text: A young man comes to you with hair loss as shown in the image given below. You prescribe finasteride to prevent his condition from worsening. Which isoform (s) of 5-alpha reductase does this drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
This man has male-pattern hair loss. Finasteride selectively inhibits type 2 5α‐reductase within the hair follicle. Hence, it is used in the treatment of male-pattern hair loss.

The 5α‐reductase enzyme converts testosterone to the more potent form of dihydrotestosterone (DHT). 5α‐Reductase exists in 3 isoforms. Type 1 and 3 are widely distributed in the skin and not involved in hair growth.

Type 2 is present in androgen-responsive tissues such as the dermal papillae of the hair follicle, prostate, epididymides, and seminal vesicles. Type 2 5α‐reductase also plays a key role in regulating androgen-dependent hair growth.

Hair growth in the following areas is androgen dependent:

  • Beard, chest, and extremity hair in males
  • Scalp, pubic, and axillary hair in both sexes 

Male-pattern hair loss: 

Male-pattern hair loss causes thinning of the vertex and an M-shaped receding hairline, as shown below. High levels of circulating androgens stimulate hair loss in certain sites by a process called miniaturization. Finasteride reverses this process.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the efficacy of oral contraceptive pills. Out of 100 women who took the pills, 10 women became pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl Index?
questions.solution:
The Pearl index is calculated to be 5 per hundred woman years.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this scenario, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10.

There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

We arrive at this: Pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per hundred woman-years

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked by the red arrow and its nerve supply.

choices.text: Mylohyoid; posterior division of mandibular nerve
Medial pterygoid; trunk of mandibular nerve
Lateral pterygoid; anterior division of mandibular nerve
Masseter; anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the medial pterygoid muscle. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

The medial pterygoid is a part of muscles of mastication. The muscle is identified by the lingual nerve, which runs on the surface of the medial pterygoid. The motor innervation for the muscles of mastication arises from the special visceral efferent column in the pons. 

The mandibular nerve is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve and is a mixed nerve. It gives sensory innervation to the teeth and gums of the mandible, skin in the temporal region, part of the auricle, lower lip, the lower part of the face, anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the oral cavity. The motor innervation is given to the muscles of mastication, tensor veli palatini, tensor tympani, mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric.

The mandibular nerve, after supplying the medial pterygoid, divides into anterior and posterior divisions. 

Muscles of mastication

Medial pterygoid:

It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

 

Lateral pterygoid:

It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/ opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Temporalis:

It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Masseter:

It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted into the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: All of the following indicate MgSO4 toxicity in a patient receiving anti-convulsive MgSO4 therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Overdose of MgSO4 is associated with loss of patellar reflex. Hyperreflexia is not seen in MgSO4 toxicity.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for the signs of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate at <12 breaths/min (Option B)
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, slurred speech, Somnolence, and drowsiness (Option C, D)

The following clinical features occur with the overdosage of MgSO4.

Clinical response Serum levels of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 8-12
Warmth and flushing 9-12
Somnolence 10-12
Slurred speech 10-12
Paralysis and respiratory difficulty 15-17
Cardiac arrest 30-35

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with watering, pain, and photophobia in his left eye for the past 6 weeks. He reported having similar episodes in the past. The results of fluorescein staining of his left eye are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).
Antivirals are the first line of therapy.
It is a linear branching ulcer with tapered ends.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic corneal ulcer, which is an irregular, zigzag linear branching ulcer with knobbed ends (not tapered ends) as seen in the image as well.

A dendritic corneal ulcer is pathognomonic of the herpes simplex infection.

Herpetic simplex keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and herpes viral keratitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea. (Option A)

Signs & Symptoms:

  • The classic herpetic lesion consists of a linear branching corneal ulcer (dendritic ulcer). The ulcer is initially superficial and spreads in all directions as grey striae, which extend and increase in length. 
  • Patients with epithelial keratitis complain of foreign-body sensation, light sensitivity, redness, and blurred vision associated with focal or diffuse reduction in corneal sensation. (Option B)
  • In patients who are immunocompromised due to pre-existing disease or using corticosteroids, the ulcer may become large; in such cases, the lesion is called a geographic ulcer.
  • Stromal keratitis manifests as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema.

Treatment:

Topical antivirals are the first-line treatment. (Option C)

  • Trifluorothymidine 1% drops four times a day for 5 days, acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day for 21 days, or 3% vidarabine ointment five times a day for 2 weeks
  • Systemic antivirals in cases of increased severity or recurrence
  • Topical antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: During the ward rounds, the consultant posts the following patients for certain procedures. In which of these patients would you expect a higher chance of surgical-site infection?

choices.text: Patient posted for elective Nissen fundoplication
Patient posted for elective orthopedic arthroscopy

questions.solution:
The patient posted for elective Nissen fundoplication (option B) indicating a clean-contaminated wound has a higher chance of surgical site infection rate among all the other options provided. All other options are categorized as clean wounds.

Class I: Clean wounds: Surgical-site infection (SSI) rate is least in clean wounds, i.e. in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered.

Examples:

  • Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)
  • Elective splenectomy is a clean wound categorized as class I
  • Elective orthopedic arthroscopy is also categorized under Class I Clean wounds.

Class II: Clean-contaminated wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination.

Examples:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (e.g. fundoplication)

Class III: Contaminated wounds include open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered.

Class IV: Dirty wounds include old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the emergency room with fever, headache, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. MRI is done for the patient, which is given below. What is the standard treatment for the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI showing multiple ring-enhancing lesions suggest a diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin is the standard treatment in this patient. 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Clinical manifestations include altered mental status, seizures, weakness, cerebellar signs, meningismus, cranial nerve manifestations, etc.

The diagnosis is usually based on the MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations. However, a single lesion may also be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, which show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes, an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring called the eccentric target sign, which is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnosis: Other conditions having single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include

  • Primary CNS lymphoma
  • TB, fungal or bacterial abscesses. 

Treatment:

  • Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 
  • Alternative regimens are clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, and azithromycin +pyrimethamine + rifabutin.

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis is to prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection, given to patients with IgG antibodies to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double-strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given. The same regimen also offers primary protection against Pneumocystis jirovecii. 
  • Secondary prophylaxis/ maintenance therapy is to prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts are <200/μL. Sulfadiazine/ pyrimethamine and leucovorin are given. Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months. 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: CNS infections and regions commonly affected

INFECTION REGION COMMONLY AFFECTED
Tubercular meningitis Basal part of the brain
Tubercular encephalitis Intra parenchymal granulomas
Meningovascular Neurosyphilis Base of the brain and meninges covering the cerebral convexities
Paretic neurosyphilis Frontal lobe
Tabes dorsalis(syphilis) Dorsal column of spinal cord
HSV encephalitis Temporal and frontal lobes
Varicella-zoster infection Dorsal root ganglia, Trigeminal ganglia
Cytomegalovirus Choroid plexus and paraventricular subependymal regions
Poliomyelitis Anterior horn cells of spinal cord
JC virus Oligodendrocytes
Rabies Hippocampus cerebellum
HIV Subcortical regions
Aspergillosis/ Mucormycosis Blood vessel walls, Intraparenchymal abscesses or granulomas
Cryptococcosis Intra parenchymal abscesses or granulomas(soap bubble appearance)
Toxoplasmosis Cerebral cortex(near grey matter-white matter junction)
Cerebral malaria Blood vessels of brain

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic patient presents to your OPD with severe restlessness, palpitations, flushing, and sweating. He was started on metronidazole about 3 days back for an infection. On enquiring, he admits that he consumed two shots of whiskey after taking his medications. Which of the following medications is least likely to produce a similar reaction?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario of the patient developing severe restlessness, palpitations, flushing, and sweating following the consumption of alcohol along with his medication suggests a disulfiram-like reaction. Levofloxacin is least likely to produce a disulfiram-like reaction. 

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor. It leads to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and its subsequent manifestations. So, when alcohol is co-administered with disulfiram, it causes unpleasant reactions in the patient like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

Drugs that are capable of causing a disulfiram-like reaction:

  • Metronidazole
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine
  • Ritonavir
  • Cephalosporins containing a methylthiotetrazole group like cefoperazone, cefotetan, cefmetazole, and cefamandolec

Disulfiram should only be taken after the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. The disulfiram-alcohol reaction can occur for 1 or 2 weeks after the last dose of the drug.

questions.text:
Choose the false statement(s) about triple sugar iron (TSI) media.
  1. A pink color indicates fermentation of sugars.
  2. Blackening of the media indicates H2S production.
  3. Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.
  4. It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.
questions.solution:
All the statements mentioned above are true about the triple sugar iron (TSI) medium except that a pink color indicates fermentation of sugars. Fermentation of sugars is indicated by yellow color on the TSI medium.

TSI medium is a composite medium and is used for the identification of isolates. It is convenient and economical as a single composite medium indicates different properties of the bacterium.

It indicates whether bacteria ferments glucose only or lactose and sucrose also, with/without gas formation. It also indicates H2S production.

  • If the slant and the butt turn yellow, all the sugars (glucose, lactose, sucrose) are fermented.
  • The blackening of the media indicates H2S production.
  • Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.

It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.

Examples of composite media:

  1. TSI medium
  2. Bile esculin medium - differentiates between Enterococcus (group D) and other streptococci

questions.text: Which of the following committees is responsible for establishing the Medical and Health Education Commission?
questions.solution:
The Shrivastav committee recommended the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission for planning and implementing the reforms needed in health and medical education on the lines of the University Grants Commission.

The Shrivastav Committee was formed in the year 1975 as a “group on medical education and support manpower”. The committee was established for the following purposes:

  • To devise a suitable curriculum for training a cadre of health assistants so that they can serve as a link between qualified medical practitioners and multipurpose workers
  • To suggest steps for improving the existing medical educational processes so as to provide due emphasis on the problems particularly relevant to national requirements

The group recommended immediate action for the following: 

  • Creation of bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers from within the community itself (e.g., school teachers, postmasters, gram-sevaks) to provide simple, promotive, preventive, and curative health services needed by the community
  • Establishment of 2 cadres of health workers, namely multipurpose health workers and health assistants, between the community-level workers and doctors at the PHC
  • ROME scheme- Reorientation of Health Education
  • Establishment of the Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Development of a 'Referral Services Complex'

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
All the features mentioned above are seen in background diabetic retinopathy except intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities. They are seen in the pre-proliferative stage of diabetic retinopathy.

Background diabetic retinopathy is a collective term used to describe the earliest changes in diabetic retinopathy. 

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background diabetic retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative diabetic retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy:

  • Neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD)
  • Neovascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old man, at a distance of 1 meter, you find that the red reflex was moving against the movement of the instrument. How will you interpret your findings?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. Since the red reflex moves against the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as having myopia of more than 1D.

Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1 m is as follows:

  • No movement of red reflex - Myopia of 1D
  • With the movement - Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D
  • Against the movement - Myopia more than 1D

Retinoscopy is an objective method of finding out the refractive error by the method of neutralization.

The patient is made to sit in a dark room, and light is directed onto the patient's eye. If a cycloplegic has been used, the patient can look directly into the light and have the refraction assessed along the actual visual axis.

Neutralization: When the red reflex moves with or against the movement of the retinoscope, we do not exactly know the measure of refractive error. Therefore, to estimate the degree of refractive error, the movement of the red reflex is neutralized by the addition of increasingly convex (+) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving with the movement of the retinoscope) or concave (-) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving against the movement of the retinoscope).

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The parameters in the given clinical scenario indicate that the Apgar score in this newborn is 7:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the cylinder shown below?
  1. This cylinder contains oxygen.
  2. Maximum pressure in this cylinder is around 745 psi.
  3. The pin index of this cylinder is 2,5.
  4. The critical temperature of the gas inside this cylinder is -119 ºC.
  5. The gas inside this cylinder is present in liquid form at room temperature.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an oxygen cylinder and Statements 1,3 and 4 are correct regarding the oxygen cylinder.

Salient features of oxygen cylinder:

  • Black cylinders with white shoulders are used to store oxygen.
  • The pin index of the oxygen cylinder is 2,5. 
  • The maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psi. 
  • The critical temperature of oxygen is -119 ºC; hence, it is present in the gaseous form at room temperature.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text:
Among the statements given below, all are true regarding bisphosphonates except that _________.
  1. They are used to treat Paget's disease and hypercalcemia.
  2. They inhibit osteoclast function.
  3. Oral preparations are advised to be taken with food.
  4. They can be used in patients with creatinine clearance of <30 mL/min.
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding bisphosphonates except statements 3 and 4. Oral preparations are advised to be taken on an empty stomach and are not recommended in patients with creatinine clearance of < 30 mL/min.

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They act by directly inhibiting osteoclast function, thus preventing bone resorption. It inhibits bone resorption by inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts and inhibition of the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway. 

They are poorly absorbed from the intestine and have very low bioavailability, which is further reduced upon interaction with food and medication. Hence, bisphosphonates should be taken after an overnight fast, on an empty stomach, and at least 30 minutes before breakfast. 

It is excreted unchanged by the kidneys and it declines proportionally with kidney function and is hence not recommended for patients with a creatinine clearance of less than 30ml/min. 

Bisphosphonates are used to treat Paget's disease, tumor-associated osteolysis, and hypercalcemia. It can also be used to treat osteoporosis, including post-menopausal and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Oral bisphosphonates can cause adverse effects like gastroesophageal reflux, esophagitis, and esophageal ulcers. Intravenous bisphosphonates are associated with flu-like symptoms. Both oral and intravenous bisphosphonates can cause renal toxicity, hypocalcemia, osteonecrosis of the jaw, and atypical femur fractures.

Because of the adverse effects, oral bisphosphonates are contraindicated in the following settings:

  1. Patients with esophageal disorders such as achalasia cardia, esophageal stricture, Barrett's esophagus, or if they are unable to stay upright for at least 30 minutes after taking the medication.
  2. Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate(eGFR) of <30 to 35 mL/min.
  3. After any bariatric surgery in which surgical anastomosis is present in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.

questions.text:
A bedridden hemiplegic patient was brought to the hospital with å lesion over the back, as shown in the image. All of the following are true about the diagnosis, except _______.

VAC- Vacuum-assisted closure

choices.text: The most common site is the ischium.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is bedsore or pressure sore. All of the above statements are true about pressure sores except stage 2 is full-thickness skin loss up.

Stage 2 corresponds to partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis.

Pressure sores, also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers, are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.

Staging system for the description of pressure sores:

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.

Management:

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. They can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Fecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases.

The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

The following is an image showing VAC:

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.solution:
The image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain. . The area marked with a red arrow is the 4th ventricle.
