questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man who sustained trauma to the scrotal area a few days back came to the hospital with sudden onset of pain in the perineal and scrotal area, with blackening of the scrotum, as shown in the image. Which of the following statement is false with respect to this condition?

choices.text: It is usually not a surgical emergency.
Alcoholism is a predisposing factor for this condition.
It occurs due to a mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and image showing black, necrotic skin over an inflamed scrotum indicate that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and it is a surgical emergency. 

Fournier's gangrene is characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissue of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is necrotizing fasciitis with rapid onset gangrene, which leads to the exposure of the scrotal contents.

Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus, and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. It may occur after minor injuries or procedures done in the perineal region.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: a mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene formation

It presents with sudden pain, pyrexia, and prostration. There may be a foul-smelling exudate and crepitus may be present. The testes are usually not affected. Cellulitis spreads and involves the skin and coverings of the scrotum, and penis. This may get sloughed and expose the testes, which remain healthy. It is also referred to as "shameful exposure of the testis." 

It is a surgical emergency.

  • Initial management is by intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Urgent wide surgical excision of dead and infected tissue is essential.

Despite the best therapy, mortality rates have been reported to be as high as 50%.

questions.text: A patient who was started on penicillamine subsequently presented with facial swelling. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Histological image of the kidney biopsy is shown below. What will be the finding on immunofluorescence?

choices.text: Granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane
Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions

questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. This image along with the clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome depicts membranous nephropathy. Immunofluorescence, in this case, will show granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane. 

Almost 75% of membranous nephropathy is primary and the rest is due to

  • Drugs such as penicillamine, captopril, gold, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Malignant tumors of the lung and colon
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders such as thyroiditis

Other options:

Option B: Linear deposition of antibodies(IgG) is seen in anti-GBM antibody disease.

Option C: Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions is seen in IgA nephropathy.

Option D: Effacement of the foot process is found in the electron microscopy picture of membranous nephropathy and minimal change disease.

questions.text: According to NTEP, how will you classify a TB patient who had taken antitubercular drugs for only 3 weeks in the past?
questions.solution:
Under NTEP, a new case is defined as a TB patient who had never taken ATT previously or taken ATT for <1 month.

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 30th week of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up. On sonographic imaging, her amniotic fluid index was found to be 30 cm. An intern examining the patient would find all of the following findings, except _____.

choices.text: History of taking angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi)

questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 30 cm suggests a diagnosis of polyhydramnios. An intern examining the patient would find all of the following findings except for a history of taking angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, which is associated with oligohydramnios. 

Polyhydramnios can be defined as the presence of excessive amniotic fluid. Clinically, an ultrasound evaluation of an AFI >24 cm and the deepest vertical pocket (DVP) measuring >8 cm (Option D) can be termed polyhydramnios.

It can be caused by both maternal and fetal abnormalities. Common fetal causes include anencephaly and esophageal or duodenal atresia. Common maternal causes include multiple pregnancies, diabetes, and cardiac or renal disease.

Patients may present with dyspnea, palpitations, and pedal edema. On examination, the following findings can be elicited:

  • Markedly enlarged abdomen with flank fullness
  • Tense, shiny skin with striae
  • Fundal height more than the appropriate gestational age (Option A)
  • Fetal parts and the presentation cannot be well-defined (Option C)
  • Fluid thrill present

On per vaginal examination, tensed bulging membranes can be felt. Investigations to confirm the diagnosis include an ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis and an evaluation of possible causes.

It can lead to fetal complications like prematurity and congenital abnormalities. Maternal complications include the development of pre-eclampsia, premature rupture of membranes, and malpresentation.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with cystic neck swelling as shown in the image. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. Which of the following malignancies may develop from this, if the swelling remains untreated?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is a thyroglossal cyst. The most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is an infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant, with the most common type of cancer being papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a duodenal diverticulum who underwent surgery the previous day and has been nil per os since the surgery complains of abdominal pain. The surgeon was wearing a bracelet with a coin attached during the surgery despite being warned by the nurse. The abdominal radiograph is shown below. Under which doctrine will the surgeon be held responsible?
questions.solution:
The image shows a coin in the abdomen that was absent before the surgery. As the patient was nil per os after the surgery, this implies that the coin from the bracelet had fallen inside the abdomen during the surgery and the surgeon completed the surgery without removing it. The surgeon will be held responsible under res ipsa loquitur.

Res ipsa loquitur means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." It implies that the negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. The patient has to only state the negligent act. This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually.
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A - Res indicata is a defense for the doctor against negligence. This specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed beyond two years would be dismissed as it would be beyond the period of limitation.

Option C - Contributory negligence is the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant along with the doctor's negligence contributing to the injury without which the injury would not have occurred. It acts as a partial defense against negligence for the doctor. In the given scenario, the patient was nil per os, indicating that there was no provision for foreign body consumption and suggesting there is no contributory negligence by the patient.

Option D - Medical maloccurrence occurs when the patient does not respond properly or faces adverse effects in spite of good attention and care by the doctor.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: You are a part of a project that involves the quality improvement of patient care in the hospital. The plan of the project is given below. What is the duration of the critical pathway in the project?
questions.solution:
The critical pathway would take 11 days in the given project plan. 

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. Here, the longest pathway consists of "Start---> task B---> task C---> Finish," which is (5+6) 11 days.

Although task D is the longest activity taking 7 days, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with severe retrosternal chest pain, sweating, and breathlessness for the last 20 minutes. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. The treatment option most appropriate for this patient is percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when there is an occlusion of one or more arteries supplying the heart. This leads to an imbalance between myocardial oxygen demand and supply, leading to myocardial ischemia and death. 

Treatment of MI primarily involves control of discomfort, fibrinolysis, and reperfusion therapy. Reperfusion therapy includes both PCI and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). 

In PCI, a stent or balloon is inserted into the occluded artery to restore blood flow. It is done under local anesthesia and mild sedation. In CABG, a vessel is grafted from a different part of the body and is used to restore blood flow by bypassing the occlusion. It is a surgical procedure. CABG is generally preferred for severe left main and three-vessel disease. 

Reperfusion therapy should be done as soon as possible, within a few hours of the onset of symptoms. It has better short-term and long-term outcomes when compared to fibrinolysis alone. 

Other options: 

Option A - Aspirin and ibuprofen are given to patients with acute pericarditis. 

Option B - Cardioversion is done in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Coronary artery bypass grafting is preferred in patients with severe multivessel disease. 

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: Which of the following conditions aggravates digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia aggravates digoxin toxicity.

Conditions aggravating digoxin toxicity:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypernatremia
  • Inhibitors of P-glycoprotein: Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide (they decrease digoxin clearance)
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia: Diuretics, corticosteroids, amphotericin B

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter, thereby increasing the intracellular sodium levels. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity are ventricular tachycardia, partial-to-complete A-V block, severe bradycardia, and atrial fibrillation/flutter.

Adverse effects of digoxin:

  • Cardiovascular toxicity of digoxin includes extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, and AV block, and in patients with structural heart disease, it can cause ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.
  • GI toxicity includes anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • It can cause headache, fatigue, and sleeplessness.
  • In the eye, it can cause altered color perception and halos.

Purified Fab fragments from ovine antidigoxin antisera (Digibind) are used as antidote for digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: A patient visits your clinic for follow-up after a breast surgery. She undergoes an x-ray scan, the findings of which are given below. Which of the following complications, if present in this patient, would show the linguine sign on MRI?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows silicone breast implants in a patient. MRI showing the linguine sign in post-silicone breast implant patients indicates intra-capsular silicone rupture.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the linguine sign. It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

Intracapsular rupture on MRI.

Breast implants are technically simple and it facilitates achieving symmetry. The implant in submuscular plane is better whenever a muscle is not removed during surgery. If the muscle is removed as in radical mastectomy, then a subcutaneous implant is placed. Silicone gel implants are used.

Complications may include pain, exposure of implant and rupture, infection, calcifications, displacements, intracapsular or extracapsular rupture and silicone granulomas.

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of conservative breast surgery  
  • To assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer 
  • It is the best imaging modality for women with breasts implants
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women with a positive family history.

Generally, ultrasound(USG) is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. (Option-B)

Other options:

Option B: In the case of extracapsular rupture of the silicone implant, it is detected by snowstorm appearance on USG.

Option C: Risk of anaplastic large cell lymphoma of scar tissue is increased in breast implant patients. This is confirmed by biopsy.

Option D: Calcifications in post-implant surgery patients can be detected on X-ray film. MRI used to detect contractures.

The given image below shows the siliconoma on silicone breast implants and the HP section shows silicone granulomas following silicone leak:

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter that the obstetrician is measuring in the image below is _______.
questions.solution:
The AP diameter that the obstetrician is measuring is the diagonal conjugate.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾").
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4").
  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm.

The clinically diagonal conjugate is measured, and the obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. A USG performed shows a twin gestation. Based on the USG, you deduce that the division of the inner cell mass occurred on day 3. Describe the chorionicity and amnionicity of the twin gestation.
questions.solution:
Division of the inner cell mass on day 3 results in a dichorionic diamniotic type of gestation.

Time of division Type of twin
<4 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoined twins

The following radiological signs help in the determination of the chorionicity and the amnionicity of a twin gestation.

Lambda sign: In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

T sign: It is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia (as shown in the picture) presents with an episode of dehydration and shock, requiring hospitalization. Levels of which of the following would be increased in the infant?
  1. Cortisol
  2. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
  3. 17-hydroxyprogesterone
  4. Serum androgens
  5. Plasma renin
questions.solution:
Ambiguous genitalia (virilization) with dehydration and shock (salt-wasting crisis) suggests the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Lab investigations would reveal cortisol to be decreased while 17-hydroxyprogesterone, ACTH, serum androgens, and plasma renin would be increased.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a set of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired synthesis of cortisol. This cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of ACTH, which leads to adrenocortical hyperplasia.

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH. The synthesis of both cortisol and aldosterone requires 21-hydroxylation, hence both hormones are deficient. These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension. Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males
Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra
Glans clitoris Genital tubercle Glans penis

Vestibular bulbs

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum

Corpus spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

Lower part of Vagina 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
Greater vestibular glands/Bartholin's glands Urogenital sinus Bulbourethral glands/Cowper's glands
Granulosa cells Sex cords Seminiferous tubules and Sertoli cells
Round ligament Gubernaculum Gubernaculum testis
Epoophoron and paroophoron Mesonephric tubules Efferent ductules and paradidymis
Gartner duct (remnant structure) Mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct Epididymis, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct
Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix and the upper vaginal wall Paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct Prostatic utricle and the appendix of testis (remnant structure)

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: A young man presents with multiple mucosal ulcers. On examination, Nikolsky sign is positive. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing the intercellular deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 3 is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is caused due to the production of antibodies mainly against desmoglein 3. Rarely, antibodies against desmoglein 1 can also be found. The antibodies are commonly IgG antibodies.

Desmoglein 3 is mainly present in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa. The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and mucosal ulcerations. Patients show a positive Nikolsky sign (on applying the pressure, the epidermis separates from the dermis).

Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc. Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

Direct immunofluorescence will show the deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes in the epidermis.

It is treated with steroids, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, etc.

Other options:

Option A: Antibodies against desmoglein 1 are mainly seen in pemphigus foliaceous. They are visible as scattered, scaly lesions involving the seborrheic areas of the scalp, face, chest, and upper back. Mucosal involvement is not seen in this condition.

Option C: Desmoglein 2 is not a target for the antibodies in immunobullous diseases.

Option D: Antibodies against desmoplakin are found in paraneoplastic pemphigus. The lesion is commonly associated with non‐Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Castleman disease, thymoma, and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. It is characterized by stomatitis; conjunctivitis that may lead to scarring; and esophageal, genital mucosal, and flexural involvement, with bullous and erosive lesions.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

 Dermatitis herpetiformis

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes for a regular gynecological check-up. Pap smear testing showed HSIL. Therefore, biopsy was done, which showed dysplastic changes in 2/3rd of the epithelial thickness. What is the diagnosis?

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is cervical intraepithelial neoplasia II (CIN II).

CIN is the histopathological description of a partial/full-thickness stratified squamous epithelium replaced by dysplastic cells arranged in a disorderly manner (abnormally altered morphology). However, the basement membrane remains intact, distinguishing it from cervical cancer.

Diagnosis is mainly based on routine screening as most women are asymptomatic (some may complain of postcoital bleeding/discharge or postmenopausal bleeding). Routine screening should start with sexually active (for more than three years) women above 21 years of age and should be repeated every 3-5 years until the age of 65 years.

Pap smear testing is done to identify cervical dysplasia, and the findings are classified according to the Bethesda system of cytology reporting, as follows:

  • Atypical squamous cells: Ascus - atypical cells of undetermined significance and ASC-H - cannot rule out high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL): includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL): includes CIN II and CIN III
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

As the presence of an infection can produce false-positive findings, human papillomavirus (HPV) testing is also done along with Pap smear screening. Patients who are found to have HSIL are further subjected to biopsy. This is done by colposcopic study for the visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) for acetowhite areas and taking biopsies of abnormal areas.

CIN, along with multiple sexual partners and infection with HPV strains 16, 18, 31, and 33, is a major predisposing high-risk factor for cervical cancer; thus, the need for routine screening in women.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the Intensified Mission Indradhanush Scheme?

choices.text: A total of 12 vaccines are included in this scheme.
Children and pregnant women benefit from this.
4 rounds of immunization are held for 7 days in each month.
Yellow fever and typhoid vaccine were added newly.

questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine and yellow fever vaccine are not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days in each month (from the 7th-13th of each month):

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

This is a potential question under recent updates in PSM. 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It was launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was brought to the casualty ward after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 44 breaths/min, and a BP of 90/40 mmHg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on the involved side of his chest. What will be your next, immediate step?

choices.text: Needle thoracostomy in 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Needle thoracostomy in 2nd intercostal space in midclavicular line

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The next, immediate step of management is inserting a needle in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS). 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy, i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety 

Note: According to ATLS 10th edition,

  • For adults, the location of needle thoracostomy or needle decompression has been changed to the 5th ICS, anterior to the midaxillary line from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • For the pediatric age group, the location of needle thoracostomy remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Which of the following components is a part of the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Literacy rate is one of the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). All other options are components of the human development index (HDI).

Physical Quality of Life Index measures three indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Life expectancy at age one
  • Literacy rate

For each indicator, the performance of a country is rated from 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best performance. PQLI is calculated by taking the average of the three indicators, with equal weightage for each of the indicators. 

The index is used for international and national comparisons. It measures the results of social, economic, and political policies. The PQLI does not take into account the per capita income of the country. Therefore, the Middle Eastern countries that are rich, have a lower PQLI compared to Sri Lanka or the state of Kerala in India.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text:
Given below are a few of the important ophthalmic lesions encountered during routine clinical practice. Match the ophthalmic findings to the specific vitamin deficiencies they are associated with.
  1. Vitamin D
  2. Vitamin B12
  3. Vitamin B1
  4. Vitamin B2
  5. Vitamin A
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2, E-1.

Image A - Corneal vascularization. Seen in riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency.

 

Image B - Retrobulbar neuritis with partial optic atrophy. Seen in thiamine/ Vitamin B1 deficiency.

The image depicts partial optic atrophy with pale discs. In retrobulbar neuritis of nutritional origin, the fundus is initially normal. 

 

Image C - Bitot's spot. Seen in Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Image D - Bilateral centrosecal scotoma. Seen in toxic amblyopia/ nicotinic amblyopia. The principal reason behind the visual defect is a deficiency of Vitamin B12/ Cobalamine.

 

Image E - Zonular cataract. Seen in the deficiency of vitamin D. 

 

The various ophthalmic manifestations of common vitamin deficiencies is summarised in the pearl below.  

Related Pearl: Ophthalmic manifestation in vitamin deficiency

Vitamin deficiency Ophthalmic manifestation
A
  • Xerophthalmia
B1
  • Corneal anesthesia
  • Conjunctival and corneal dystrophy
  • Acute retrobulbar neuritis
B2
  • Photophobia
  • Burning sensation
  • Vascularization of the cornea
B12
  • Bilateral centrocecal scotoma
C
  • Hemorrhage in eye
D
  • Zonular cataract
  • Papilledema

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with chest pain and diaphoresis. ECG demonstrates ST-segment elevation, and coronary angiography shows transient vasospasm. The patient is prescribed nitrates. Which of the following drugs can be added to treat this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Prinzmetal/variant/vasospastic angina. The first-line agents that are used are calcium channel blockers (CCBs) and nitrates.

Prinzmetal angina occurs as a result of vasospasm of the epicardial coronary artery. It may result in transient transmural ischemia. The cause of this spasm is not well understood and is suspected to be due to hypercontractility of cardiac smooth muscles.

This type of angina is commonly seen in women under 50 years of age and is precipitated by smoking and cocaine use.

The vasospasm leads to transmural ischemia, which is seen on the ECG as transient ST-segment elevation although there is no atherosclerosis present on angiography. 

Depolarization of cardiac myocytes depends primarily on the influx of Ca2+ ions. Ca 2+ antagonists relax arterial smooth muscle, thereby decreasing arterial resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac afterload.

So, calcium channel blockers such as long-acting nifedipine and amlodipine are employed along with nitrates to alleviate vasospasm.

Other options:

Option A: Beta-blockers are not used in the management of vasospastic angina and may worsen the symptoms.

Option C: Aspirin is speculated to worsen vasospasm in vasospastic angina, and hence, it must be avoided.

Option D: Although angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are commonly used antihypertensives, they are not used as first-line agents in the management of Prinzmetal angina.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: An autopsy is being conducted on a person who was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus. An axial dissection of the brain reveals one of the ventricles that is enlarged in this disease. Enlargement of the anterior horn of this ventricle causes compression of which of the following structures laterally?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an axial section of the lateral ventricle seen from posterior to anterior. The lateral relation of the anterior horn is the caudate nucleus. Enlargement of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of the caudate nucleus laterally.

The clinical symptoms of normal-pressure hydrocephalus are characteristic of the classic triad of cognitive dysfunction, urinary symptoms, and a wide-based gait (wet, wacky, and wobbly). Additionally, depressed affect and UMN signs in lower limbs may be seen.
The diagnosis is established by a CT that shows a marked enlargement of ventricles and the Miller Fisher test that shows improvement in gait following a lumbar tap. Treatment generally involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

The lateral ventricle can be divided into the body and 3 horns—anterior, posterior, and inferior.

The locations of the parts: 

  • Body: Frontal and parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn: Frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn: Occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn: Temporal lobe

Anterior horn:

Extent: from the genu of the corpus callosum till the interventricular foramen

Relations: 

  • Anteriorly: Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof: Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 
  • Floor and lateral wall: Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

Body or Central part:

Extent: from the interventricular foramen till the splenium of the corpus callosum

Relations:

  • Roof: Body of the corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum 
  • Floor (from lateral to medial): Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

Posterior horn: 

Extent: from the splenium till the occipital pole

Relations:

  • Roof and lateral wall: tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

Inferior horn: the largest compartment

Extent: till 2.5 cm from the temporal pole

Relations:

  • Roof: tapetum of corpus callosum and tail of caudate nucleus
  • Floor (lateral to medial): Collateral eminence (produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus)

Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with lethargy, constipation, and weight gain, with a poor appetite for a few months. The thyroid profile revealed a high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and low free T4 levels. Which of the following features will most likely be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Increase in blood flow to skin

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with elevated TSH level and low level of free T4 is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Among the given options, a reduction in stroke volume is the feature most likely to be seen in hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism leads to a decrease in myocardial contractility and pulse rate, resulting in reduced stroke volume and bradycardia.

Enzymes involved in regulating calcium fluxes in the heart are controlled by thyroid hormones, including the calcium-dependent adenosine triphosphate and phospholamban.

In hypothyroidism, the expression and activity of these enzymes decrease so that it could potentially impair systolic performance and diastolic relaxation.

Expression of the beta-adrenergic receptor is also decreased in hypothyroidism, resulting in a reduced response to a catecholamines-mediated increase in inotropy. 

The thyroid hormone relaxes the vascular smooth muscle and reduces peripheral vascular resistance. Conversely in hypothyroidism, the release of endothelial-derived relaxing factors is decreased causing a contraction of smooth muscle and, thereby, an increase in peripheral vascular resistance (option A) leading to hypertension. 

This change causes a reduction in stroke volume and tissue perfusion. This leads to an inflow of blood away from the skin (option C) and results in cold extremities.  

Pericardial effusion occurs almost in 30% of cases with hypothyroidism (Option B). In hypothyroidism, the permeability of the epicardial vessels will increase and lymphatic drainage of albumin will decrease. This results in the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space.

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

In primary hypothyroidism, TSH will be elevated and free T4 is low.

Patients with hypothyroidism who have no evidence of heart disease are managed with levothyroxine 50 to 100 mcg daily. The goal of the treatment is to maintain TSH in the lower half of the reference range.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by posttranscriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: An elderly male, who is a chronic smoker, presented with painless, gross hematuria. An ultrasound of the kidney, ureters, and bladder shows no visible abnormality. Which of the following is the most important diagnostic investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggests a possible diagnosis of bladder cancer. But negative ultrasound findings do not rule out bladder cancer. Hence, the most important diagnostic investigation for this patient is cystourethroscopy.

It facilitates the visualization of any abnormality on the surface of the bladder and aids in taking biopsy samples. It is used in the transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT). It is also used to follow up on patients with carcinoma in situ.

Bladder carcinoma is characterized by painless, gross hematuria. It is the most important symptom. It might lead to the formation of clots and subsequent urinary retention. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain due to nerve involvement.

Smoking and exposure to urothelial carcinogens such as benzidine and naphthylamine are some of the most important risk factors. Bladder cancer is also increasingly prevalent in people working in the textile, leather, and dye industries.  

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is classified into 3 types:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70%) are exophytic tumors that grow into the bladder cavity.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancers are large irregular ulcers with a broad base.
  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ is characterized by the presence of irregularly arranged cells that have large nuclei.

Urine cytology that shows the presence of malignant cells is highly sensitive. Complete urinary tract imaging with CT and MRI is used for the assessment of extravesical spread and metastasis. This helps to determine the stage of the tumor and its appropriate treatment plan.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: Intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection, with/without neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options:

Option A: A bimanual examination is done before and after TURBT. It is done to ensure the complete removal of the tumor.

Option D: Intravenous urography studies show a filling defect. But they have been largely replaced by non-contrast CT and MRI studies.

Option B: Non-contrast CT and MRI are used for the clinical staging of the disease prior to traetment options like TURBT.

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial) Smoking
Exposure to aniline dyes
Cyclophosphamide
Pelvic irradiation
Squamous cell carcinoma Schistosomiasis (S. haematobium)
Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
Bladder diverticula
Chronic UTI
Smoking
Adenocarcinoma

Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations:

  • Gain of function mutation in FGFR3
  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase
  • Disruption of p53 and RB genes in muscle-invasive cancers

questions.text: The injury shown in the image results from:
questions.solution:
The injury shown in the image is suggestive of a scald burn, which results due to the application of moist heat commonly involving only superficial layers of the skin.

Moist heat includes

questions.text: Two brothers presented with bilateral painless progressive visual loss. After a thorough examination and investigation, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. The pedigree chart shown in the image below was drawn to explain which family members may be affected (colored red). Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows mitochondrial inheritance, and the condition showing this pattern of inheritance is Leber optic neuropathy.

The mitochondrial pattern of inheritance is when the mother is affected and the father is normal, which leads to all their children (both male and female) being affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria. The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria, if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.

Therefore, while the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offspring (both male and female), only the daughters of the affected mother can further transmit the disease.

 

Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance are as follows:

The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.

There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 

The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria, which can lead to oxidative dysfunction; this phenomenon is called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.

Also, during cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Other options:

Option A: Ocular albinism is inherited as X-linked recessive or autosomal recessive disease.

Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa may be inherited as autosomal dominant, recessive, or X-linked based on the involved genes.

Option C: Leber congenital amaurosis is inherited as an autosomal recessive inheritance.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presents with a history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, neck rigidity is present, and hip and knee flexion occurs on passive flexion of the neck. The findings of the cerebrospinal fluid analysis are given below. Identify the organism responsible.

Opening pressure - 200 mmH2O

WBCs - 7000/µL, with neutrophil predominance

CSF glucose concentration - 1.2 mmol/L

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2 

CSF protein - 0.7 g/L

Latex agglutination - positive

Limulus lysate test - negative
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and CSF examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae. 

Although all the other organisms are also causative of bacterial meningitis, the Limulus lysate test is negative. The Limulus amebocyte lysate assay test is positive in gram-negative organisms and Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive organism. The test has a specificity of 85–100% and a sensitivity approaching 100%.

The classic clinical triad of fever, headache, and neck rigidity is suggestive of meningitis. Other common complaints are nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. Nuchal rigidity (“stiff neck”) is the pathognomonic sign of meningitis. Hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck is called Brudzinsky's sign.

Following are the classical CSF examination features suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

Opening pressure  >180 mmH2O
WBC

10/μL to 10,000/μL; neutrophils predominate
RBC Absent in non-traumatic tap
Glucose

<2.2 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL)
CSF/serum glucose <0.4
Protein

>0.45 g/L (>45 mg/dL)
Latex agglutination

May be positive in 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Escherichia coli, group B streptococci
Limulus lysate Positive in gram-negative meningitis
Culture Positive in >80%

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with mood lability, sadness, and tearfulness 5 days after delivery. She has no thoughts of harming the baby. There is no history of previous mood disorders. There is no family history of mood disorders. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postpartum blues and the preferred treatment is supportive therapy.

Mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolve spontaneously are characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness. These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If the symptoms persist longer than two weeks, evaluation is indicated for postpartum depression.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Which of the following components helps differentiate interstitial fluid from plasma?
questions.solution:
The lower protein levels help to differentiate interstitial fluid from plasma. 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) compartment includes interstitial fluids and plasma. The plasma and the interstitial fluid are separated only by highly permeable capillary membranes because of which the ionic composition of fluids in both these compartments are similar. The most important differentiating factor is the lower concentration of proteins in the interstitial fluid. This is due to the low capillary permeability to the proteins that are present in plasma. 

In contrast to the intracellular fluid (ICF), the ECF has an abundance of sodium, chloride, calcium and bicarbonate ions, and lesser amounts of potassium, phosphate, and magnesium ions. The image below depicts the proportion of the important anions and cations present in the intracellular and extracellular fluids. 

Related Pearl: Extracellular fluid vs Intracellular fluid

  Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Na+ 142 mEq/L 10 mEq/L
K+ 4 mEq/L 140 mEq/L
Ca++ 2.4 mEq/L 0.0001 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L 4 mEq/L
HCO3- 28 mEq/L 10 mEq/L
PO₄³⁻ 4 mEq/L 75 mEq/L
Glucose 90 mg/dL 0-20 mg/dL
Proteins 2 g/dl (5mEq/L) 16 g/dL (40 mEq/L)
pH 7.4  7.0
Osmolarity 282 mOsm/L 281 mOsm/L
Major Cation Na+ K+
Major Anion Cl- Phosphate
Buffer HCO3-

Protein

Phosphate
Most osmotically active ion Na+ K+

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. His x-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is correct about the condition?

choices.text: Histology of the lesion shows multi-nucleated giant cells.
The tumor is seen more commonly in children.
Reactive sclerosis around the tumor is always seen.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing a soap bubble appearance is suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT)/ osteoclastoma. The histological finding in GCT would be multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells. 

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years (Option B), with slight female predominance. It is exclusively seen in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones (Option C). GCT is seen most commonly in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT:
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor (Option D).

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like the distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.
