questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with an enlarged, hard, nodular prostate. Further investigations reveal a tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle. Other adjacent structures are not involved. What is the stage of his disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of the tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle and not to other adjacent structures is T3b.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA level)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

questions.text: A 1-month-old male baby was brought to you with complaints of a left-sided flank mass. The mother reported that the child cries while urinating and had been treated with antibiotics for urinary tract infection. Ultrasonography was done and revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system, with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the ultrasonograph showing hydronephrosis of the affected kidney indicate a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) associated with UTI.

Hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound; it can, however, be transient or mild and resolves on its own. Re-evaluation should be done after birth and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and in cases of failure to thrive.

If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness. It needs to be ascertained whether the other kidney is involved, the lower ureter is dilated, the bladder wall is thickened, and whether emptying of the bladder is incomplete. Based on these findings, a diagnosis can be made.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Other options:

Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis after UPJ obstruction. In vesicoureteric reflux, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective; hence, abnormal backflow of urine occurs from the bladder into the ureter. It may also present with hydronephrosis; however, the distal ureter is also involved, unlike in this case.

Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. Since the distal urinary tract is normal-looking in this case, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. As a result, bilateral hydronephrosis and bladder dilatation is seen, unlike the unilateral involvement in this case.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of easy fatigability, weight loss, and an evening rise in temperature. The bone marrow aspirate of a patient is shown in the image given below. What subtype of acute myeloid leukemia is the patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the bone marrow aspirate showing faggot cells—promyelocytes with numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm—is highly suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia M3 (AML-M3) or acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Acute myeloid leukemia is a spectrum of hematological malignancies where poorly differentiated cells of the hematopoietic stem cells infiltrate the blood and bone marrow. They are the most common acute leukemias in elderly people. Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes an individual to the development of AML.

The criterion for making a diagnosis of AML according to WHO requires one of the following:

  • Blast cell count of ≥20% either in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Blast cell count of <20% in the presence of any one of the following three cytogenetic abnormalities:
    • t(15;17) 
    • t(8;21) 
    • Inversion 16 or t(16;16)

Clinically, AML presents symptoms resulting from pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalized fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies, and an increased risk of recurrent infections. 

AML-M3, or acute promyelocytic leukemia, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). 

Histopathology of the bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Sometimes, multiple Auer rods cluster together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).

The condition is associated with a high incidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Treatment includes the administration of all-trans retinoic acid.

The image given below shows faggot cells.

questions.text: The vector in the following image can transmit all of the following diseases, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a hard tick. It transmits all the diseases mentioned above except rickettsial pox, which is transmitted by the house mice mite.

A hard tick's head is visible as it is situated at the anterior end, whereas a soft tick's head is not visible from above because it lies on the underside of the body. A chitinous shield covers the entire back in males and females have a small portion of scutum in the front.

The hard tick transmits the following diseases.

  • Tick typhus (Rickettsia conorii)
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Kyasanur forest disease
  • Tularemia, tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis (Babesia microti)
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia rickettsii).

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with a history of chronic constipation since birth. Physical examination shows marked abdominal distension. Abdominal radiography reveals distended bowel loops with the absence of air in the rectum. A rectal biopsy shows an absence of ganglion cells in the muscle wall and submucosa. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities may be associated with the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with a rectal biopsy showing an absence of ganglion cells in the muscle wall and submucosa is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. Among the given conditions, the abmormality most likely to be associated with Hirschsprung disease is trisomy 21, i.e., Down syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease, or congenital aganglionic colon, is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus. In the fetus, migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall for the formation of the enteric nervous system is completed by the 24th week of life. Abnormalities in this migration due to premature arrest or death of ganglionic cells result in Hirschsprung disease.

It is more common in males. Risk factors include Down's syndrome and RET oncogene mutations affecting neural crest cell migration. 

Hirschsprung disease is associated with various conditions:

  1. Trisomy 21/Down syndrome
  2. Smith–Lemli–Opitz syndrome
  3. Shah–Waardenburg syndrome
  4. Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 syndrome
  5. Neurofibromatosis
  6. Neuroblastoma
  7. Urogenital or cardiovascular abnormalities.

It causes a muscular spasm of the distal intestinal segment, resulting in functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation (megacolon). The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

The image given below shows dilated ganglionic and contracted aganglionic segments in Hirschsprung's disease:

 

The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrograffin enema.

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel.

The image given below shows a contrast enema in Hirschsprung's disease:

 

A rectal suction biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis and operative intervention is the definitive treatment.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to be pregnant with 8 weeks of amenorrhoea. She has 2-year-old twins who were born at 35 weeks gestation and had one stillborn baby 3 years back at term. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score according to the GPAL system?
questions.solution:
For the given patient, the obstetric score according to the GPAL system is G3P2A0L2.

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GPAL system - 

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
  • A - Abortion - the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason before 20 weeks of gestation. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, ectopic or molar pregnancy.
  • L - Living children at present

Therefore in this patient,

  • G - 3 (The patient has 3 pregnancies in total, including the present pregnancy)
  • P - 2 (The patient has 2 pregnancies that crossed 28 weeks, excluding the present pregnancy)
  • A - 0 (The patient has no abortions)
  • L - 2 (The patient has 2 living children currently)

GTPAL system is also used which is as follows -

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • T - Term delivery, any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks
  • P - Preterm delivery, number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days. Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm. 
  • A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks
  • L - Living children at present

 For the given patient, the GTPAL score is G3(1+1+0+2).

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the marked ligament "X". According to DeLancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral ligament (marked "X") is injured. 

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body

  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma drugs is approved for the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis?
questions.solution:
Bimatoprost is an antiglaucoma drug approved for topical application in the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis (the presence of less than the normal amount of hair).

Bimatoprost is a PGF-2 alpha analog. PGF-2 alpha analogs are associated with eyelash hypertrichosis; hence, it is used in hypotrichosis of the eyelashes. Bimatoprost is also used in the treatment of ocular hypertension and open-angle glaucoma.

Adverse effects of bimatoprost include iris and eyelid pigmentation; it can also cause upper respiratory tract infection in about 10% of patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, who was diagnosed with a ventral hernia, is planned for mesh hernioplasty. The mesh is considered to be well placed if it covers all margins of the defect by a distance at least ________.
questions.solution:
The mesh should cover all the margins of the defect by at least 20 mm (2 cm) for it to be considered as a well-placed mesh. A well-placed mesh should have good overlap around all the margins of the defect by at least 2 cm and up to 5 cm if possible.

Mesh hernioplasty involves placing a tension-free prosthetic mesh over the hernia defect. It also strengthens the hernia repair after the defect is closed with sutures. Sometimes, a 3-dimensional mesh is kept in the defect to prevent future herniation through the defect. 

The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.

Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.

Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltration, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less than other meshes. This results in fewer adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and less patient discomfort and pain than that observed with other meshes. 

Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological mesh depending on their composition.

Synthetic meshes are more commonly used these days. They are made from polymers of polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). 

Polypropylene Polyester PTFE
Monofilament multifilament solid
Hydrophobic hydrophilic hydrophobic
Rigidity elastic rigid

PTFE meshes are hydrophobic and have a higher risk of adhesion compared to polyester meshes.

Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have fewer complications than other meshes. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength, and hence, their use is restricted to infected environments. 

Note: Microporous meshes (e.g, ePTFE) and multifilament meshes are at higher risk of infection because macrophages and neutrophils are unable to enter small pores (< 10 μm). This allows bacteria (< 1 μm) to survive unchallenged within the pores and braids.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is placed in a lithotomy position, and the external opening is found to be located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
The likely location of the internal opening is the 6'O clock position, which is the posterior midline of the anal canal.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano, with the external opening located at the 11’O clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. This means that the anal margin is located anterior to the coronal midsection. The location of the internal opening of the fistula can be identified using Goodsall's rule.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly tract in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Thus, according to the exception to Goodsall's rule, this patient likely has an internal opening at the 6'O clock position as the external opening is located more than 3 cm from the anal margin track. 

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue. It has a primary internal opening in the anorectal lumen and a secondary external opening in the perianal skin. An anal fistula may be present if the patient has Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, malignancy, foreign body, lymphogranuloma venereum, or actinomycosis. Patients usually present with intermittent discharge and pain. 

Intersphincteric fistulas are the most common type. Other types of anal fistulae are transsphincteric fistula, suprasphincteric fistula, and extrasphincteric fistula.

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes with complaints of abdominal cramping and breast pain that is cyclical and occurs once a month. It is associated with headaches and difficulty concentrating at work. She notices that the pain begins a week before menstruation and resolves after menses. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premenstrual syndrome.

Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses. 

The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty in concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis. 

Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, limiting salt intake, and symptomatic treatment of breast tenderness and pelvic pain. Vitamins B1, B6, and E may be used.

Other options:

Option A: Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the cramping pain that accompanies menstruation and is most pronounced on the first and second day of menses.

Option B: Periductal mastitis is a chronic relapsing infection of the subareolar duct of the breast. It can manifest as subareolar pain and erythema. Repeated infections can lead to scarring that causes inversion or retraction of the nipple, subareolar masses, etc. 

Option C: Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic benign endometrial tissue that occurs outside the uterine cavity. Patients present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

questions.text: A 55-year-old, alcohol-dependent male patient presented with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. The patient reports that this is a recurring problem even after repeated medical interventions. On auscultation, basal crackles are heard bilaterally on the chest fields. He is visibly icteric, and his fingers show clubbing. The nurse prepares the following tray for a procedure. Which quadrant of the abdomen is preferred when performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a large-volume paracentesis is to be done to remove ascitic fluid secondary to likely liver pathology. The left lower quadrant is preferred because of the greater depth of ascites and the thinner abdominal wall.

After evaluation of the patient and confirmation of ascites, the etiology of the ascites is best determined by paracentesis. 

Paracentesis is a bedside procedure in which a needle or small catheter is passed transcutaneously to drain ascitic fluid from the peritoneum. The lower quadrant is the most frequent site for paracentesis. The left lower quadrant is preferred because of the greater depth of ascites and the thinner abdominal wall. Paracentesis is a relatively safe procedure even in patients with coagulopathy.

Complications are seen but are infrequent and include the following:

  • Abdominal wall hematomas
  • Hypotension
  • Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Infection

Refractory cirrhotic ascites is defined by the persistence of ascites despite sodium restriction and maximal (or maximally tolerated) diuretic use. When medical therapy is insufficient, refractory ascites is managed by repeated large-volume paracentesis (LVP). Patients undergoing LVP should receive IV albumin infusions of 6–8 g per liter of ascitic fluid removed. Intravenous infusion of albumin accompanying LVP decreases the risk of “post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction” and death. Post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction (PPCD) is characterized by the activation of the RAAS system and increased renin levels. It causes rapid re-accumulation of ascitic fluid.

Indications of paracentesis:

  • Diagnostic -
    • New-onset ascites for fluid evaluation
    • Refractory ascites
    • Suspected spontaneous or secondary bacterial peritonitis
  • Therapeutic -
    • Respiratory compromise secondary to ascites
    • Abdominal pain or pressure secondary to ascites

Contraindications :

An acute abdomen requiring surgery is the only absolute contraindication. Relative contraindications include elevated PT/INR and pregnancy.

The following image shows the instruments included in a paracentesis tray:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with complaints of excessive bleeding during menstruation, accompanied by a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. Her periods last for 8-10 days and are associated with the passage of clots. An ultrasound of her pelvis reveals a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass. She has completed her family and does not wish to preserve her fertility. Which among the following drugs is not helpful in the shrinkage of this tumor prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of heavy menstrual bleeding with pelvic heaviness and the ultrasound image suggest a diagnosis of uterine fibroid (leiomyoma). Tibolone does not reduce the size of leiomyoma.

Tibolone is a synthetic derivative of 19-nortestosterone and has a weak oestrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic action. It is used as add-back therapy to reduce the side effects of GnRH therapy by counteracting the antiestrogenic effects. It does not interfere with the size of the fibroid. It elevates the mood, relieves vasomotor symptoms, improves the sex drive, and reduces bone resorption. Its main action is cardioprotection by reducing the level of triglycerides.

Drugs used to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, triptorelin, nafarelin
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulators (SPRMs) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil

Other medical methods used in the treatment of fibroids:

  • Levonorgestrel Intrauterine device - controls bleeding effectively
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)
  • Tranexamic acid 
  • Iron therapy for anemia
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss, without interfering with the size of the fibroid. 

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery embolization - Angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic resonance–guided focused ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

 

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text:
Which of the following can transport a substance against its concentration gradient?
  1. Simple diffusion
  2. Secondary active counter-transport
  3. Secondary active co-transport
  4. Primary active transport
  5. Facilitated diffusion
questions.solution:
Secondary active counter-transport, secondary active co-transport, and primary active transport can transport a substance against its concentration gradient.

Simple diffusion refers to the process of random movement of a substance along its concentration gradient.

Facilitated diffusion: Transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other is done with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients. Glucose transport by the glucose transporter is an example, which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

 

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. An example of one such protein is SGLT 1, the cotransporter of sodium and glucose from the intestinal lumen into mucosal cells.

 

Active transport is the transporting of substances against the gradient and requires energy. Ca2+-ATPase that pumps out calcium out of the cells is an example.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: An autopsy conducted on a patient who died of pulmonary embolism showed thrombosis of deep veins of the legs. Which finding suggests an antemortem venous thrombosis?

choices.text: Red thrombus with lines of Zahn
White thrombus with lines of Zahn
Red thrombus with "chicken fat" upper portion
White thrombus with "chicken fat" upper portion

questions.solution:
Red thrombus with lines of Zahn is suggestive of antemortem venous thrombosis.

Antemortem clots: They have microscopic laminations called lines of Zahn, which have pale layers (platelet and fibrin) alternating with dark (RBC-rich) layers signifying their formation in flowing blood.

The images given below show the lines of Zahn:

 

Postmortem clots: They are bland and nonlaminated. They are gelatinous and have a dark red lower portion, where RBCs settle down by gravity, and a yellow "chicken fat" upper portion.

Related Pearl: Arterial and Venous Thrombi

Feature Arterial thrombus Venous thrombus
Pathogenesis Endothelial injury or site of turbulence Stasis of blood
Blood flow Associated with active blood flow Associated with sluggish blood flow
Sites Coronary, cerebral and femoral arteries Superficial and deep leg veins, ovarian periuterine veins
Propagation Grows in a retrograde manner from point of attachment Grows in an antegrade manner from point of attachment
Line of Zahn Present Present
Microscopic

Friable meshwork of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and degenerating leukocytes (White thrombi).

 Red cells mixed with relatively less platelets, so also called as red thrombi
Occlusion Incomplete lumen occlusion Complete vessel occlusion
Complications Ischemia and infarction of organs Embolism, edema and ulceration

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby is brought with a history of diffuse, ground-glass-like corneal haze in both eyes. She has large corneas with excessive lacrimation, and an inability to keep her eyes open in a bright room. Tonometry revealed an intraocular pressure of 30 mmHg. All the given findings are associated with the infant's condition, except ____.

choices.text: Thinned sclera in the ciliary region

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with raised intraocular pressure is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. All the findings mentioned above are seen in this condition, except that the corneal diameter is <13 mm.

Normal infant cornea measures 10.5 mm. A diameter of >13 mm confirms corneal enlargement in congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP), which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. Onset is usually less than 3 years of age.

Trabeculodysgenesis (defective trabecular meshwork) is the mechanism of raised IOP, simulating open-angle glaucoma. The CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis of congenital glaucoma. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. 

Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm form the classic triad of symptoms of congenital glaucoma.

The signs seen in congenital glaucoma are as follows:

  • The hazy cornea/ground-glass appearance of the cornea is the earliest sign seen in glaucoma. It is seen due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Haab's striae - Horizontal or concentric breaks in Descemet's membrane resulting in discrete corneal opacities
  • Blue sclera - The stretching of the sclera results in its thinning in the ciliary region, giving rise to a bluish color.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Corneal edema and enlargement result in raised corneal diameter >13 mm (normally, 10.5 mm). Prognosis is poor if the diameter becomes more than 16 mm.
  • Myopia due to stretched eyeball, resulting in increased focal length

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required. IOP measurement, anterior chamber examination, optic disc examination, corneal diameter measurement, gonioscopy, and assessment of refraction are warranted.

Management is essentially surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy. If angle surgery fails, trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has had unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now presents with blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. With a high suspicion of giant cell arteritis, you order a panel of investigations. Which of the following laboratory results should prompt you to consider a different vasculitis as your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of headache, jaw claudication, visual changes, and polymyalgia rheumatica in an older woman suggests a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis/ temporal arteritis. Elevated serum creatinine levels are not expected to be seen in giant cell arteritis/ temporal arteritis and should prompt further evaluation of other vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis due to the involvement of small renal arteries. GCA being a large vessel arteritis, rarely causes derangements of renal function. 

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have signs of superficial temporal artery inflammation, including erythema, pain on palpation, nodularity, thickening, or reduced pulsation on the affected side. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. It is also associated with mononeuritis multiplex, which is characterized by peripheral neuropathy in two or more separate nerve areas.

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness.

Elevated ESR and anemia, usually normochromic or slightly hypochromic are characteristic laboratory findings. Raised liver enzymes, especially alkaline phosphatase are common. Levels of IgG and complement may be raised. However, serum creatinine levels are not elevated.

Histopathology of giant cell arteritis shows panarteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation. Intimal thickening and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina are also seen.

The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery. 

The mainstay of treatment in GCA is steroids. Prednisolone 40-60 mg is given for one month followed by tapering doses. The duration of treatment is approximately 2 years or more. Methylprednisolone 1000 mg for 3 days should be given to patients presenting with visual symptoms.

Aspirin reduces the occurrence of visual loss and can be given in addition to steroids. Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig). Both these drugs are used adjunctively to steroid therapy.

Related Pearl: Primary Forms of Vasculitis with Sites of Involvement

  Giant cell arteritis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

(Wegener's granulomatosis)

 Churg Strauss syndrome PAN Leukocytoclastic vasculitis Buerger's disease Behcet disease
Aorta + - - - - - -
Medium-sized arteries + + + + - + +
Small-sized arteries - + + + + + +
Capillaries - +/- +/- - + _ +
Veins - - - - + + +

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency with lightheadedness and acute onset of severe abdominal pain. She has had amenorrhea for 8 weeks and two episodes of spotting. Her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and her pulse rate is 138 beats/minute. Her urine pregnancy test result is positive.  What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The most appropriate management for this patient is Salpingectomy. It can be done for both ruptured and unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

The other procedure is salpingostomy (Option D), which involves the removal of only the concepts, while preserving the fallopian tube. This is usually done when the contralateral fallopian tube seems abnormal and when the ectopic pregnancy is unruptured.

Management of tubal ectopic pregnancy:

Medical management is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. It involves the systemic or local use of chemotherapeutic drugs: 

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly).
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-hCG

Medical management is likely to be successful when

  • Initial serum hCG level is <5,000 IU/L.
  • Ectopic mass is less than 4 cm.
  • Fetal cardiac activity is absent.
  • Intra-abdominal hemorrhage is absent.

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, and microsurgical laparotomy. 

Indications:

  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Failure of medical therapy- 
    • Serum β-HCG levels remain elevated 
    • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

Estimation of serum β-hCG level should be done weekly until the β-HCG values go down.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with severe dyspnea, mild fever, joint pains, and joint swelling. He has had similar episodes in the past. Examination revealed mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. Echocardiography showed small warty vegetations along the lines of the closure of the mitral valve leaflets. How long will you give secondary prophylaxis to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with repeated episodes of severe dyspnea, mild fever, arthralgia, joint swelling, mitral stenosis, and warty valvular vegetation is likely to have rheumatic heart disease. Since he is a 34-year-old with carditis with residual valve disease, he should receive prophylaxis until he is 44 years of age. 

Secondary prophylaxis is given to patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. 

In those with rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, prophylaxis should be given for 10 years after the last episode or till they attain 40 years of age (whichever is longer). As he is 34 years of age, providing prophylaxis for 10 years till he attains 44 years of age is longer than until he turns 40.

Lifelong medication can be continued in severe valvular disease or postintervention (after valve surgery) patients.

The best antibiotic for secondary prophylaxis is benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks. Oral penicillin V (250 mg) can be given twice daily instead, but is less effective than benzathine penicillin G. Patients who are allergic to penicillin can receive erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

Category

Duration after the last attack

Rheumatic fever without carditis

  

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

  10 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought with complaints of vomiting and altered consciousness. She was recently diagnosed with an influenza infection and was started on an antipyretic for fever. Laboratory tests showed increased levels of liver enzymes but normal serum bilirubin levels. What could have been the prescribed antipyretic in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggests an adverse reaction to the given antipyretic medication and describes Reye's syndrome. Reye's syndrome can be precipitated in children with viral infection and concomitant use of salicylates like aspirin.

Reye syndrome is an acute encephalopathy that may follow a viral upper respiratory tract infection (influenza or varicella). It is precipitated in a genetically susceptible person by the interaction between viral infection and exposure to salicylates and/or antiemetics.

Clinically children present with acute onset vomiting and features of encephalopathy like delirium, altered consciousness, confusion, and lethargy.

Liver dysfunction is present in all cases and presents with coagulopathy and laboratory evidence of elevated serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and ammonia. But, bilirubin levels remain normal and the patient does not develop jaundice.

A biopsy of the liver in a patient with Reye's syndrome shows microvesicular infiltration of fat in the hepatocytes. Reye syndrome is a life-threatening adverse effect, and patients must also be screened for fatty acid oxidation and fatty acid transport defects.

Another salicylate medication that risks the development of Reye's syndrome is bismuth subsalicylate.

Other options:

Mefenamic acid, ibuprofen, and acetaminophen are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs that can be used as antipyretics in children and are not associated with the development of Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: An anesthetist is performing the regional block technique shown in the image given below. This technique cannot be used for analgesia/anesthesia in which of the following conditions/procedures?
questions.solution:
The image shows a needle at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid. This procedure is used in superficial cervical plexus block. This cannot be used to provide analgesia for a dislocated shoulder.

Interscalene blocks are used to provide regional anaesthesia for conditions of the shoulder like shoulder dislocation.

The cervical plexus is derived from the C1, C2, C3, and C4 spinal nerves and innervates prevertebral muscles, strap muscles of the neck, and the phrenic nerve. The superficial cervical plexus provides a cutaneous sensation of the skin between the trigeminal innervation of the face and the T2 dermatome of the trunk. The deep cervical plexus innervates the musculature of the neck.

Cervical plexus blocks (CPB) are techniques of regional anaesthesia that is used to provide anaesthesia/analgesia in various head and neck surgeries.

The superficial cervical block is achieved by inserting a 22-gauge needle, at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The needle is inserted 4 cm deep, and 5 mL of the solution is injected along the posterior border and the medial surface of the sternocleidomastoid.

This technique can be used for surgeries like

  • Carotid endarterectomy 
  • Thyroidectomy
  • Tracheostomy
  • Lymph node dissection
  • Plastic surgery repairs
  • Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy
  • External ear surgery

The complications that may occur are inadvertent intravascular injection; phrenic nerve injury (rare); blocking of the accessory nerve, leading to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscle weakness; and puncture of the internal jugular vein and carotid artery.

This technique is contraindicated if there is an active infection overlying the injection site, contralateral phrenic nerve palsy, previous neck surgery and radiation, and allergy to injected drugs.

Interscalene block results in the blockade of the superficial and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. To perform this technique, the patient should be in the supine position, with the head turned away from the side to be blocked. The interscalene groove is palpated. A transverse line from the cricoid cartilage is drawn to intersect the interscalene groove. This point of intersection indicates the transverse process of C6 where the drug is administered.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, an ASHA worker would make 5 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

The woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. The ASHA worker should ideally make the first visit on day 7 and, thereafter, 4 visits till day 42.

Home visits of ASHA workers post delivery:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text:
The image given below shows the mechanism of a component of the immune system's first line of defense against infection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the release of these substances from the cell?

SLE- Systemic lupus erythematosus

choices.text: It results in the loss of nucleus.
It is effective only against bacteria.
It is implicated in the pathogenesis of  SLE.

questions.solution:
The gif shows fibrous neutrophilic extracellular traps (NETs) released from a neutrophil. NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses). They are detected in the blood during sepsis. They are produced by neutrophils in response to

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
